I was really proud to talk to my community about the work that our government has been undertaking, including establishing the National Women's Health Advisory Council. This has brought together diverse expertise to examine the unique challenges that women and girls experience in the health system.

The Chisholm Women's Health Forum allowed the Assistant Minister for Health and Aged Care, Ged Kearney, who attended virtually, along with Professor Helena Teede, director of the Monash Centre for Health Research and Implementation at Monash University, to listen to women, hear their stories and answer their questions. An invitation was extended to every woman in my electorate of Chisholm to join the forum and to share their stories of their experiences within the healthcare system.

I really want to thank everyone who came to the forum and everyone who reached out to me with their stories of the health system. Women shared stories of missed diagnoses, delayed diagnoses and of not being listened to or believed. There were some positive stories too, of medical professionals taking the time to listen to and to communicate clearly with patients about their health. I'm really pleased that our government is prioritising women's health. Once again, I would like to thank all of the women who attended and the women who shared their stories. I'm grateful, and value their participation and contributions.

I also had the pleasure earlier this month to open the Wild at Art Showcase at the Box Hill Community Arts Centre, in my electorate. I was really pleased to attend this event and to show my support. This year, over 6,800 children picked up their paintbrushes and pens across Australia to help raise awareness of Australia's threatened plants and animals as part of the Wild at Art threatened species competition. This was facilitated by the Australian Conservation Foundation. Of the chosen pieces of artwork, 157 pieces were completed by children local to Chisholm. There were some stunning, heartfelt and very thought-provoking artworks exhibited by Australia's next generation of artists. I want to say well done and congratulations to all involved. I'm pleased to advise the House that as part of the 'Save our big backyard' campaign, which the children were advocating for, I will be championing the cause of the southern brown bandicoot, an endangered animal which used to be common in our part of the world in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne. Unfortunately, it isn't anymore. I look forward to supporting this worthy cause at home in my electorate of Chisholm, and in this place through my role here.

I've said previously in this place, many times, that it's a great privilege to be the member for Chisholm. It has always been important to me that I take the time to listen and engage in the lives of the people in my community in a meaningful way, and I'm really grateful for every moment in my electorate that I'm able to do that. I want to thank my community for the many invitations to attend events and I want to thank everyone who has taken the time to attend my many mobile offices in the electorate, and those who have contacted my office. The engagement and support of my community allows me to be a better representative.
Debate interrupted.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023

p.span: Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.
to which the following amendment was moved:

That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "the House declines to give this bill a second reading until a Senate inquiry into the bill has reported, and notes that:
(1) the Government's industrial relations changes will make life tougher for Australian businesses by increasing costs, complexity and red tape and as businesses say will likely lead to job losses;

(2) the Minister has admitted in his own public comments that this bill will add complexity to an already complex workplace relations system, and increase prices for consumers for everyday services they have come to rely on;
(3) this bill does nothing to address Australia's weakening economy and falling productivity;
(4) the bill does not assist Australian businesses to hire more people, and just ticks off even more items on the unions' wish list including new right of entry laws and new union delegate rights;

(5) despite the Minister promising 'carve-out' for small business, all the Government has done is add more complexity and made it harder for small and medium businesses to navigate the industrial relations system;
(6) the Government has failed to outline how this legislation will enhance productivity, lift wages, or generate more jobs; and
(7) at a time of a cost of living crisis, high inflation, businesses struggling with staff shortages and rapidly increasing power costs, the Government is making a bad situation worse"—
to which the following amendment was moved:
That all words after "House" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not supporting a Senate inquiry into the bill and not declining to give the bill a second reading:
(1) notes that in 2001 a far North Queensland sugar mill was sold by a bank and receivers at allegedly an undervalued asset price, leaving millions owing in original farmer shareholders;
(2) notes that despite continuous calls for an ASIC investigation, the only accountability came through civil proceedings successfully brought on by affected farmers;
(3) notes that in 2012 a mine in far North Queensland collapsed placing 450 people out of work and leaving millions owing in wages and entitlements to contractors, subcontractors and suppliers;

(4) notes that in July 2023 another mine in far North Queensland collapsed placing 250 people out of work and leaving millions owing in wages and entitlements to contractors, subcontractors and suppliers;

(5) notes that both mining companies had the same Director prior to collapse and complaints made to the ATO about unpaid super for the second company date back to September 2021, nearly two years before the collapse;
(6) notes that in March 2023 a transport/wholesale fruit company collapsed leaving millions owing to transport and farming entities across Australia;
(7) notes that the Director of this company, who resigned days before the collapse, has approximately 285 office holdings in various other companies and is the subject of a number of ASIC complaints;
(8) notes that workers and contractors, subcontractors and suppliers cannot be adequately protected by regulation alone and we must have improved oversight and enforcement;
(9) notes that ASIC and the ATO either are ill-equipped or otherwise unwilling or unable to fulfill the role of a tough and accountable enforcer of companies and their officeholders; and
(10) calls on the government to:
(a) remove corporate oversight from the ATO and ASIC;
(b) place corporate oversight with the Fair Work Commission or a similar oversight and enforcement body; and

(c) provide this oversight and enforcement body with the resources, accountability and powers to adequately protect employees and contractors, subcontractors and suppliers from corporate wrong doings".
to which the following amendment was moved:
That all words after "whilst not" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"declining to give the bill a second reading:
(1) acknowledges there are over 14 200 small businesses trading in Fowler—which comprises 99 per cent of the local economy;
(2) recognises one in three small businesses in Australia are run by migrants and refugees
(3) acknowledges small businesses often do not have the resources for legal and HR professionals to dissect complex reforms
(4) recognises small business owners from culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) backgrounds may require additional education and outreach on changes to regulation and compliance;
(5) notes the bill's regulation impact statement does not adequately address red tape and compliance costs for small businesses; and
(6) calls on the Government to:
(a) conduct an in-depth analysis of the regulatory and financial impacts on small business owners before passing the bill through the House;
(b )ensure small business owners from CALD backgrounds have equal access to information, materials and support; and
(c) allow further small business consultation by respecting the Senate Education and Employment Legislation Committee inquiry's reporting date of 1 February 2024".

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Ms Vamvakinou ) (20:00): The question is that the amendment moved by the honourable member for Fowler be agreed to. I call the member for Petrie in continuation.

Mr HOWARTH (Petrie) (20:01): When it comes to subcontractors, you would think that the minister would actually talk to subcontractors. How many subcontractors—electricians, plumbers and carpenters—did the minister or his staff get out and actually talk to? I'd love to know how many there were, other than those that the union just brought in.

When it comes to casuals, the proposed changes risk severely undermining the employment contract and potentially risk casual workers having their hours significantly changed. The coalition, while in government, took confusion out of being a casual. We made changes that were to the benefit of the worker and the employer, but, in true Labor style, the current Albanese government want to relegislate the confusion.

Members might think of people in their own electorates—maybe a 19-year-old uni student or a 17-year-old school student in year 11 or 12. Back when I was a kid, people of my age would know that you worked as a casual on Thursday night and Saturday morning. Now, with longer trading hours, people do different hours. If you're a uni student, perhaps you want to work every Wednesday night, every Tuesday night and every Saturday because you've got study to do and it actually helps your family time and study time to know that you're doing those set hours. Or, if you're a year 11 or 12 student and you want to work Thursday nights and every Sunday or Saturday morning, those set hours might work around family time and other commitments that you have with sport. But not with the Labor Party. You can't have regular hours as a casual because they want to make you permanent part time or full time. They want to take that flexibility away from young people who want those hours. That's the problem with the Albanese government. They have no idea because they've employed no-one and don't know what it is actually like to employ people and the ramifications for people in their electorates.
What does the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia say in relation to this? They say:

The small business community reject the intrusion of so much more complex regulation into the ability to be productive and flexible, let alone just getting on with being in business and employing more people … The complexity and breadth of impact doesn't solve problems . It will confuse everyone …
The proposed changes will also increase the costs of all impacted businesses, leading to an increased cost of living.

This is right in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis which the government don't know about because they've spent 18 months talking about the Voice. Higher rents, higher energy bills, higher prices for goods, higher mortgages and higher food prices are a result of the Albanese Labor government. There have been 13 increases in interest rates. That's their legacy, and they want to put more costs on top of small business.

Do you remember when they were talking about same job, same pay? According to the National Farmers Federation, 'same job, same pay' is the bill that all Australians will have to pay. I agree with them, as most people in my electorate and around this country would agree: yes, there are minimum standards and minimum awards, but not everyone deserves to be paid the same. Some people work harder than others. Some people get there early, work longer and do extra hours, and they actually deserve to be paid more—but not with this mob. Same job, same pay: you're all going to be paid the same, true communist style.
Let me finish up by quoting the Australian Industry Group:
There is nothing in the Federal Government's latest workplace relations proposals that would create a single job—
not one—
add to job security, drive sustainable wage growth, raise productivity—
which we know is falling through the floor under the Albanese government—
encourage a person to start a business, encourage an employer to grow their business or would simplify our complex workplace relations system.

Mr LAXALE (Bennelong) (20:05): The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill is an important piece of legislation that stands as evidence not only of this government's commitment to fairness but also of our commitment to ensuring that all workers, regardless of their circumstances, are treated with dignity and respect. The labour market in Australia and across the world has undergone profound transformation in recent decades. Particularly since COVID we have completely reshaped the way we work, the way we live and the way we relate to employment. These changes, also driven by technological advancements, globalisation and evolving economic conditions, have undoubtedly made our lives more convenient, but they have also ushered in a new era for Australian workers. As our labour market evolves, so too must our industrial relations laws. They must adapt and improve to ensure they safeguard workers' rights and wellbeing effectively.

The gig economy has become a prominent player in our country's labour sector, offering flexible employment opportunities to a diverse range of workers. The flexibility of gig work benefits many, providing the freedom to work when and where they choose. However—and this is important—this flexibility should not come at the cost of workers' basic rights and protections. It's crucial to strike a balance between supporting this new-found flexibility and safeguarding the wellbeing of those who participate in this growing sector in our economy. That balance between rights and flexibility currently does not exist in our industrial relations system. There is an imbalance, and this legislation seeks to fix that.

With this bill, the government will preserve the benefits of the gig economy whilst ensuring that those who gig work have the rights that they deserve. Many gig workers value the flexibility and autonomy that gig work provides them, and the government has no intention of altering the fundamental aspects of their gig employment. Our goal is not to force individuals into becoming employees when they do not wish to do so. The gig economy offers a wealth of opportunities and flexibilities, but the benefits of gig work should not come at the expense of below-minimum-wage pay. We must ensure that gig workers receive fair compensation for their efforts. We must eliminate the risk of exploitation that can occur when wages fall below acceptable standards. We do not want to see a future where workers rely on tips to make ends meet. We do not want an American-style wage system here in Australia. I'm proud that Australians and Aussies are stingy tippers, because that shows that our workers are well paid, and long may that continue.

On this side of the House, we envision a future where every worker is treated and paid fairly and justly, one where tips are not essential to make ends meet. To achieve this balance, we propose to extend the powers of the Fair Work Commission to encompass employee-like forms of work, ensuring that workers in this sector are afforded the same rights and protections as their counterparts in traditional employment arrangements. This is not radical. It's about fair work, fair pay and fair conditions. This change will allow the Fair Work Commission to make orders for minimum standards for new forms of work such as gig work, creating a safety net for workers in that field. It will also provide crucial protections against unfair deactivation for gig workers where digital labour platforms have them regularly engaged for six months.

As we navigate this rapidly changing employment environment, we must ensure that small businesses are given the necessary support and flexibility to thrive in an ever-changing labour market. Small businesses are the backbone of our economy, and their resilience and determination contributes significantly to our nation's prosperity. I grew up in, and running, a small business. My first pay cheque was from my family's small business—and, yes, it was an actual cheque that I had to go to the bank to cash out. I get small businesses, and I'm glad that this legislation acknowledges small businesses' important role in our economy. Within this legislation, we are not only recognising the importance of small businesses but also providing them with the support they need to succeed and grow. That's why this legislation implements transitional arrangements and total exemptions to help small businesses get where they need to be.

In our commitment to supporting small businesses, we are taking a proactive step by developing a voluntary small business wage compliance code, in partnership with employer and employee groups. This code will help small businesses navigate the wage compliance landscape, ensuring they understand their obligations and rights under the law. Evidence of compliance with this voluntary code will not only demonstrate a commitment to fair industrial practices, but it will also shield small-business owners from criminal prosecution by the Fair Work Ombudsman. Instead of punitive action, the Fair Work Ombudsman will have the authority to issue compliance notices that require workers to be repaid if underpayments are discovered, or it may take civil action, if necessary. It's important to note that civil action is not the default for small businesses, nor should it be.

This approach is designed to foster a collaborative environment in which small businesses can thrive, while ensuring the fair treatment of our workers. This approach in this legislation exemplifies the Albanese government's commitment to finding practical, supportive solutions that empower small businesses rather than imposing unnecessary burdens. Further, it's helping small businesses support their employees. In the face of economic strain on their business, many businesses sometimes need to downsize. In the case that that business then becomes insolvent, employees who have remained employed during the downsizing lose their redundancy pay entitlements through no fault of their own. It's an issue that warrants attention and resolution.

This legislation seeks to amend the Fair Work Act to address an anomaly in the way small business redundancy exemptions operate in insolvency scenarios. Key elements to the proposal include amending section 121 of the Fair Work Act and introducing provisions that modify the application of the small business redundancy exemption when an employer goes bankrupt or enters liquidation. This modification is designed to ensure that employees who are faced with insolvency related downsizing are not unfairly deprived of their redundancy entitlements. Importantly, the proposed amendments will not change the operation of the small business redundancy exemption for solvent and viable small businesses that will continue to enjoy exemption from redundancy pay obligations. The proposed amendments are specifically designed to prevent the loss of redundancy entitlements for employees whose employers have downsized due to insolvency. This will not affect businesses that have successfully restructured or those wound up in solvent circumstances, excluding liquidations resulting from a member's voluntary winding-up.

In a nation that upholds the principles of equity and accountability, we must ask ourselves a fundamental question. If a worker steals from the cash register, it's considered a criminal offence. But when an employer pilfers from a worker's hard-earned wages, it often goes unpunished. The wage theft epidemic has plagued our nation for years, and the previous government's inaction allowed it fester. It took them years to even acknowledge the existence of this problem, and, when they finally introduced some half-hearted legislation, they voted against their own proposal when it reached the Senate. Employers who knowingly and intentionally steal from their workers pay packets should face the full force of the law. To be a country that stands up for workers' rights, we must hold those who knowingly withhold wages to account. We are taking steps to do that by introducing criminal penalties for wage theft. This will apply to employers who intentionally engage in conduct that results in underpayment and aims to address the Fair Work Act entitlements while not affecting contractual entitlements or superannuation. To ensure that criminal sanctions are reserved for those who intentionally underpay, the proposal includes mechanisms to encourage businesses to self-disclose underpayment. This bill is not about punishing employers who genuinely make a mistake. It will, however, encourage businesses to do the right thing.

The Voluntary Small Business Wage Compliance Code, developed in partnership with employer and employee groups, supports compliance and offers evidence of adherence to prevent the Fair Work Ombudsman from pursuing criminal prosecution. Instead underpaid workers will be repaid, and non-punitive actions may be taken, such as the issuing of compliance notices. In addition to the code, a cooperation agreement provides another pathway to encourage compliance. Employers who disclose potential wage theft to the Fair Work Ombudsman can enter into such an agreement, which will safeguard employees' timely repayment while ensuring that criminal proceedings are only used as a measure of last resort. Furthermore, the proposal extends liability for wage left to the Commonwealth, ensuring that the government adheres to the same standards it imposes on the private sector.

When we talk about wage theft we cannot ignore the genuine impact on its victims, like David from Ryde in my electorate of Bennelong. David had been working full time for 18 months when he resigned on 2 November 2021. Little did David know that he would become embroiled in a distressing battle against his former employer, who he later learnt had a continuous reputation for not paying his employees' entitlements, including superannuation. Since October of the previous year around 15 employees had left David's former workplace and are yet to receive their rightful entitlements.

This non-payment pattern not only jeopardises individual workers' financial security; it also contributes to a culture of exploitation, which has no place in our society. David's personal losses in this ordeal include unpaid superannuation of up to about $45,000. However, the total outstanding debt owed to the 15 individuals is staggering, reaching an estimated half a million dollars. These are not just numbers on a ledger. They represent the financial wellbeing of individuals and their families who work just as hard as we do. In response to these grave injustices, David lodged a complaint with the ATO, and the ATO, recognising the seriousness of the situation, issued a debt notice to the company's director. Yet David's former employer continues to ignore and deny the debt, perpetuating the cycle of exploitation and disregard for the rights and dignity of workers.

David's story is a stark reminder of why legislative changes like this bill are so urgently needed. This legislation is necessary, and it is the right thing to do. It's designed to protect Australian workers and to correct the injustices that have persisted for far too long. It aims to close loopholes that have allowed unscrupulous employers to exploit hardworking Australians, depriving them of wages that they have rightfully earned and the conditions that they are entitled to. It's a critical step towards safeguarding the rights of workers and ensuring that all Australians can enjoy the benefits of a fair and just workplace.

The fair work amendment bill is a significant step towards building a more just and equitable society. It closes the gaps in our existing labour laws, ensuring that all workers are protected from exploitation, discrimination and unfair treatment. This bill promotes fairness, job security and equality, while fostering a dynamic and competitive business environment.

Fair and equitable workplaces are not only what's best for Australian people; they're what's best for our economy. When workers are empowered and treated fairly they contribute to a thriving economy, strengthening businesses and building a more prosperous future for all of us. By closing loopholes in our industrial laws, this proposal ensures that every worker can confidently step into their workplace knowing that their rights are protected and that their contributions are valued. This bill is a testament to our commitment to building a society where everyone, regardless of their background or circumstances, has an equal opportunity to succeed.

Mrs ARCHER (Bass) (20:19): I proudly represent an area with a strong entrepreneurial spirit. There is an abundance of small businesses scattered across the electorate, owned and run by Northern Tasmanians who are driven to make their own way and create local employment opportunities. With just under 9,000 small businesses in Bass, I've engaged and met with many of them through my time in local government and now as a federal member, actively supporting more than 150, and counting, through my weekly small business shout-outs. I've also had the fortune of meeting many employees who are part of these businesses and who rely on these jobs for either full-time, part-time or casual income.

I consider each piece of legislation that comes before me very carefully before making a decision on how I will proceed in the best interests of the community that I represent. With 200 pages for me to examine, can you imagine the pressure on employers, as the onus is again back on them to further wade through these changes in a space that is already incredibly complex? Despite a few worthy areas that I do support, which I'll highlight later, the substance of this bill is not strong enough, at this point, to secure my vote. For the thousands of businesses in my electorate, I could safely say that there wouldn't be many, if any, who would be aware of these changes that are coming. They are too busy struggling with a number of challenges around employee shortages and rising costs—impacting their ability to keep their doors open, let alone grow—to understand what is coming their way. As their federal elected representative, I take the role of consulting with relevant stakeholders seriously, and I'm incredibly frustrated that the government has not done the same.

Business confidence in Tasmania is going well, but there is cause for concern on the horizon, as we are entering even tougher economic times and cost-of-living pressures continue to impact almost everyone. Yet the federal government keeps ducking these issues which are having a domino effect on small business owners, while also pulling vital funding for critical programs that support our community to start their own businesses. I'm not sure how that fits into the rhetoric of worker-friendly rights, when the government is actively pulling away support which provided an opportunity to build a business and an income stream. A great example of this is the Entrepreneurship Facilitator Program, which, in my electorate, had enormous success helping members of the community—overwhelmingly, women, those living with disability or those with a migrant background. In this year's budget, the Treasurer announced the program was to be cut on 30 June, just over six weeks later, without any consultation with the team behind the program.

Not that long ago, I was in one of my favourite areas of Northern Tasmania, Beauty Point, visiting a popular fish and chip shop, where the owner shared with me his frustration over increasing prices and his worry about how he will keep his shop going. Just in the last two years, a two-kilogram bag of chips has gone from $6.85 to $9.85. Cooking oil has gone up from $83 for a 20-kilo drum to over $117. And gas has increased from 85c a litre to $1.35 a litre. The owner said: 'We've only made minor price rises. If I raised prices to the level necessary to make a profit, I'm pretty sure no one would eat here.' He continued: 'We employ three people, two of which are on traineeships. I've sacrificed personally not to have to reduce their hours. We provide a tremendous amount of value to the community in terms of donations and other assistance, but I would give us less than 12 months if these costs continue to rise. We would simply be out of money to contribute.' He went on: 'This is an insane situation. Throughout Australian history, the suburban fish and chip shop has been one of the safest businesses you could possibly be in. Now, in Beauty Point alone, we've had three other food businesses close in the past two years and two more teetering on the edge.'

In addition to this stress, I do worry how this employer and a number of other small businesses will be impacted by changes to legislation—particularly around casual workers, as so many hospitality and retail businesses rely on casuals to get through their busy periods. And, let's be honest, there are many workers seeking casual employment to support them through a particular life stage where casual employment is the best option for them. As I said last year during the same job, same pay debate, I've spent the majority of my working life in casual, contract and insecure work, and, for me and many of the colleagues I worked alongside in those jobs, the casual arrangement was suitable for us at that time. But I've also lived through situations, as an employee in the hospitality industry, where employers chose not to open because of increased costs. The changes in this legislation will add additional cost to businesses, which is a no-win situation for everybody.
We all want better outcomes for workers, increased productivity and protections for both employers and employees. But the bill doesn't outline how it will successfully deliver on these key markers.

Will Cassidy, Executive Officer of the Launceston Chamber of Commerce, one of the oldest and most successful chambers in the country, expressed his concern last year over the lack of consultation on the same job, same pay bill. On this legislation he told me:

I will say that I'm concerned about the changes to the definition of casual. With the current staff shortages in just about every industry in northern Tasmania, if someone can be found to employ on a casual basis, it should be a straightforward process—not one that might cause uncertainty for a business owner—particularly in the current climate where there may not be the future capacity to convert a casual employee to a permanent position.

A few weeks ago, Robert Mallet, CEO of the Tasmanian Small Business Council, addressed the recent visit to Tasmania by the Senate Education and Employment Committee to discuss this legislation. The visit was:
… an opportunity to let legislators know that the bill is not welcome and will, through its complexity, put at risk many more Australian workers.
He went on to say:

Changes to definitions of casual labour, role of participants in the gig economy and arrangements defined by the legislation as Same Work Same Pay will do nothing to simplify an already complex minefield for employers to navigate.
In particular, the ongoing crusade by the government to convert casual employees to either full or part time arrangements.

The Bill fails to recognise that many people consciously choose to work casual hours to meet their family's or personal circumstances or needs. Inferring that they are missing out by not being part- or full-time employees will preclude possible employment elsewhere, severely impact their lives and livelihood, and effectively reduce the available labour force when there are acknowledged shortages across Australia because they may not choose to engage.
He continued:

… that the government should choose to bring forward this plethora of IR changes indicates that it doesn't trust Australian employers to do the right thing. It appears to presuppose that the government thinks that employers are out to squeeze every last advantage out of employees with little regard for their welfare.
He concluded, 'Nothing could be further from the truth.'
We've heard already from other members that business industry groups remain concerned, but their words are worth repeating here today. Jennifer Westacott said:
Australians should have safe jobs, well paid jobs and rewarding jobs, but the government's radical shake-up of the industrial relations system will not deliver that.
These changes will create confusion and extra costs for consumers, make it harder to hire casual workers and create uncertainty for employing anybody.
Any government that's serious about cost of living would not do this.
They should not add cost and complexity at a time when people are struggling to pay their bills.
The government needs to go back to the drawing board, so we are clear about the problem we are trying to solve and we're clear about the ramifications.
We need a system that takes us forward not backwards.
We need a system that drives productivity, not stifles it, because that will stifle wages growth.
The case has not been made for this radical shake-up.
The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia chair, Matthew Addison, said:

At a time when small businesses are managing increased costs of supply, of rent, of power, of wages; we don't need changes that detract businesses from their sales and service delivery. Small businesses seek to employ and properly reward their workers. They seek to innovate and adopt new technology.
We seek IR changes that enhance productivity and opportunity, not broad impacting confusion about what they are and aren't allowed to do.

Small business reject the proposed legislation. A full impact assessment of the changes must be conducted before the legislation is properly considered. The cost to implement any changes, the cost of advice, the loss of productivity as workforce flexibility is challenged by these changes.

We seek adequate time to properly analyze the detail that is now available. We argue that Government does not seek to rush these changes into law. There is a significant increase in the questions to be answered by each small business by the proposed changes. Small Business will need to spend time and invest money in obtaining advice to ensure they are not captured if these changes were to become law. This comes at a time when 43 percent of small businesses in Australia are not profitable.
He was concerned that the reforms would 'disrupt' the small-business environment.

Of course, like anyone in this place, I abhor wage theft or underpayment on any level. While I have particular concerns that those who have tried to do the right thing but fallen short through a genuine mistake may be caught up under the wage theft provision of the legislation, I, like the Tasmanian Small Business Council, have concerns over the wording and the outcome. The language it uses is offensive, where it deals with wage theft. The TSBC does not condone, in any way, the deliberate underpayment of wages, but to brand any underpayment, particularly if it's inadvertent or a mistake, as theft is nothing short of rude. In their submission to the Senate Education and Employment Legislation Committee they said, in part:

Suggestions that small-business owners widely and knowingly engage in what is described as 'wage theft' are unsubstantiated. The suggestion that this illegal practice is so widespread as to warrant blanket legislative action is unwarranted and, we believe, derogatory.

Despite the government promising that small businesses will not be referred for criminal prosecution if they can show compliance with the new Voluntary Small Business Wage Compliance Code, this provides little comfort as the code is yet to be written.

Of course I am supportive of a few measures, including the changes to the antidiscrimination laws and of the amendment to the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act, which will simplify workers compensation and will also mean first responders have easier access to support measures and structures to help them have adequate resources to deal with their condition—an extremely worthwhile change.

Lastly, the small-business redundancy changes under the Fair Entitlements Guarantee will ensure that employees don't miss out on redundancy payments if their employer becomes a small business as a result of bankruptcy or insolvency. I would have hoped that the government would have allowed these changes to be voted on separately, as they are worthy of support. But, even so, I want my backing of these measures put on the record today.

We all want better outcomes for employees that also allow for employers, businesses and particularly small business to flourish and to increase our productivity output, but, once again, this legislation falls short.

Dr ALY (Cowan—Minister for Early Childhood Education and Minister for Youth) (20:31): I welcome the opportunity to speak on the government's Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023. This is a bill that will help meet our pledge to get wages moving again after a decade of low wages under those opposite. It is a bill that builds on this government's ambitious and robust agenda—and we make no apologies for being ambitious with our industrial relations reform agenda—by raising the floor and by improving working conditions and the rights for workers right across the country. This is a bill that will reach into every workplace in this country and make a real difference to the lives of some of our most vulnerable workers, including many young Australians.

This bill is about closing loopholes that are currently built into our industrial relations system. These loopholes undermine pay, conditions and, quite frankly, the work, health and safety of Australian workers. Some of the things that this bill will do are criminalise wage theft, introduce minimum standards for workers in the gig economy, close the forced permanent casual worker loophole and close the labour hire loophole, among other things. They will strengthen the current workplace relations framework and, indeed, provide certainty, fairness and a level playing field both for businesses and workers.

I want to use my time in this debate today to highlight a number of measures in this bill that will make a difference to young workers, who we know are overrepresented in casual work, gig work and other insecure forms of work. I do this in my capacity as the Minister for Youth, but, importantly, I do this because I have had the opportunity to meet with young workers who have spoken to me of their experiences being in insecure work, and of their dreams, hopes and aspirations for their employment. I'll highlight some of those stories as I go through my contribution to the debate today.

But, just to set this up, for so many Australians this bill will actually be life-changing, particularly for young people, because young people continue to face disproportionately high unemployment and underemployment, workplace exploitation and poor working conditions. We know that for over 40 years the youth unemployment rate has been well above the overall unemployment rate.

For those young people who are employed, more than half are casual employees. That's double the rate of the rest of the working population. And nearly half of all young workers are employed in accommodation, food services or retail industries—some of the lowest paid industries across the economy. And so many of these young people are being underpaid and are subjected to unsafe working conditions. In fact, the Grattan Institute found that 20- to 30-year-olds are almost six times more likely than 30- to 40-year-olds to be underpaid by more than $3 an hour in comparison to the minimum wage. These conditions have long existed, and they continue to have a significant impact on young workers: on their standard of living, on their wellbeing and, importantly, on their mental health. The young workers that I have spoken to have described to me the toll that being in insecure work and being in underpaid work takes on them, particularly if they're juggling study and work, as many have to these days.

For so many of them wage theft and exploitation are not an abstract concept, it's not just something that we talk about here in this place. It's actually a reality for them. Last year, I had the opportunity to host a delegation of young workers right here in Parliament House for the UnionsACT youth forum. Some of the young workers there shared their stories with me and I want to relate some of those stories today, just to show the importance of this legislation to the lives of those young people and the difference that it will make to the lives of those young people.

At this forum I heard from a 19-year-old who was picking strawberries on a farm in regional Victoria. They were being paid per container picked—per container picked!—rather than the hourly rate that they were entitled to under their award. So in effect this young person was having their wages stolen from them by their employer, who should have known better. I heard from a 21-year-old cafe worker right here in the ACT. This cafe worker noticed that her 15-minute paid break was being deducted as a 30-minute unpaid break. She had to discover that herself. And she noticed that it was also happening to all of her young colleagues in her workplace. I heard from another 21-year-old, also from the ACT, working in retail who was refused the opportunity to convert to full time despite working full-time hours. Being kept a casual meant that this young person was missing out on leave entitlements. Taking a sick day or taking a day to see family would have put him at risk of not being able to afford the rent or pay the bills.

I have personal experience of that as a young mother returning into the workforce. I worked as a casual. I was working full-time hours working as a casual and so I know what it's like. I know what it's like when your children are sick and you cannot take a day off to look after them because you know you will not be able to put food on the table that week when you miss that day. Nobody should have to live, exist at that level of insecurity because of these loopholes that currently exist in industrial relations laws.

These are just some of the many examples that were shared with me by young workers, who, for too long, have been systematically exploited in their workplaces. These are young people who feel they can't speak out for fear of retribution from their employer. These are young people who need their jobs in order to be able to study, in order to be able to live independently or even live with their parents—young people who don't have rich parents, so to speak. And for many of them, what they spoke to me about on that day was that fear that speaking out would lose them their jobs, but also the fact that they were the ones that had to find out what their rights were when their employers should have been upholding their rights for them.

The stories that I have just shared were highlighted to me by young people, who asked me not to use their names today, and are very clear examples of a system that's failing to protect these young people. And it's those young people that will benefit most from this bill. It's a bill that actions what this government talks about, which is protecting workers. It doesn't just talk about protecting workers; it actually does something to do that.

When I attended the event that I mentioned earlier, some of the young workers there also presented me with a time capsule. It's a little see-through container. Inside that time capsule they wrote down on pieces of paper their hopes and aspirations for employment, and they gave it to me and they locked it. That time capsule sits in my office. It's a reminder both of the progress we're making and of the work that is still left to do. I'm heartened that we've managed to tick off so many of the hopes that are iterated and expressed in that time capsule and that this bill will tick off so many more. I'm proud to stand here today as part of a Labor government that's delivering on a number of the things that are highlighted in those hopes.

Here are some examples. Molly, who's 23 years old, wanted to see more secure work in retail and hospitality. Well, this bill will help achieve that by replacing the definition of 'casual employee' to better capture the reality of many young people's employment in casual work. William, who's 20 years old, wrote in the time capsule that he wanted to see increased penalties for wage theft. That's what this bill does. It increases the penalties for wage theft—increasing maximum civil penalties for contraventions of the Fair Work Act. As many of my colleagues have said before, if a worker steals from the till, that's a criminal offence. It's widely accepted that that's theft. But, in many parts of Australia, if an employer steals from a workers' pay packet, why is that is not considered theft? Why is that not considered a criminal offence? Employers who intentionally—and I mark that word 'intentionally' because I've heard some of the arguments from the other side—steal from their workers should face criminal penalties. It's a no-brainer. If you steal it's a crime. You should face penalties.

The previous government did absolutely nothing to stop wage theft. It took them years to even acknowledge that there was a problem. Then they brought in some legislation, and, lo and behold, they voted against their own legislation in the Senate and ended up tearing it up. They couldn't even get their own legislation through. We're sending a different signal. We're sending a different signal to business owners and we're sending a different signal to people who are affected by wage theft. We are saying that business owners, employers, who knowingly withhold wages should face the harshest penalties, and under this legislation they will.

Nicholas, who's 25 years old, said he wanted to see the system better cater to different working situations and styles. Now, I recognise that flexible work arrangements are part of a modern employment system and some people, yes, do prefer casual work and prefer gig economy work as well, but others don't; others do it because they have to. My dad didn't choose to be a casual bus driver when he came to Australia. He did it because he couldn't get a job in his field of engineering, and that's the case for a lot of migrants. Mohamed the neuroscientist driving the Uber didn't choose to be an Uber driver. He's doing it even though he's a neuroscientist.

Why shouldn't those people have minimum standards like anyone else? Why should they be treated as small businesses, when their conditions are those of employees? And why shouldn't we have rules in place to protect them, just as we have rules in place to protect anyone else? Again, to me that's an absolute no-brainer. Sure, there are people who choose to work in the gig economy for the flexibility of it, there are people who choose to be in casual employment for the flexibility of it and there are people who choose to be in different types of employment for the flexibility of it. We want them to retain that level of choice, but we also don't want them to be the lesser. We want them to have the same standards. We want them to have the same rights. We want them to have the same work health and safety that any other worker gets.

These are not radical changes. They are necessary changes, which will benefit more than 1.5 million workers across the economy. In my home state of WA, more than 160,000 people will benefit from these reforms. Under a Labor government, the more than two million young workers below the age of 25 across the economy can feel reassured that we take their workplace rights seriously. Under a Labor government, young Australians will continue to be valued, continue to be heard and continue to be respected, because we know that young people's inclusion in decision-making leads to better outcomes for young people, for their communities and for our entire country.

For those young workers who have given me the privilege of their time and the privilege of sharing their stories of how the loopholes in the current legislation have a real and tangible impact on their lives, on their wellbeing and on their mental health, I say, first of all, thank you and, secondly, I am proud to stand here and support a bill that will close those loopholes and improve the working conditions for you and future generations.

Dr RYAN (Kooyong) (20:46): The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023 will amend the Fair Work Act 2009 to enact several measures. Possibly the most notable of these are the changes to the definition of casual employee and the employee choice pathway for eligible casual employees to change to permanent employment.

The bill also aims to reinstate a multifactor test to determine if a worker is an employee or an independent contractor. It protects workers from having their wages undercut by labour hire and introduces a criminal offence for intentional wage theft. It will allow the Fair Work Commission to set standards for some, but not all, gig economy workers and road transport industry workers. It also includes measures related to workers compensation claims and protections from discrimination for employees who have been or who continue to be subjected to family and domestic violence.

It's generally accepted that there is an urgent need for minimum standards for gig workers. By and large, these workers are currently engaged as contractors, and they're consequently often not entitled to minimum wage protections. This bill creates a new class of employee-like workers, who will gain the protection of the Fair Work Commission on minimum standards. Independent contractors on digital platforms will be covered—they will be deemed employee-like—if they are receiving pay at or below the rate of an employee performing comparable work. Workers can also be deemed employee-like if they have low bargaining power or low control over the performance of their work.

At the heart of this bill is a desire to protect workers—especially gig workers, those in the care economy, those in aged care and those in the National Disability Insurance Scheme and other services where low-paid contractors can undercut full-time employees. We know that they need these protections. For example, there's extensive evidence of low-pay incentive-based payment methods and related poor safety in the road transport industry and in food delivery services.

It is appropriate for the government to concentrate on wage theft as it has done. However, employees and employers have expressed concern to me that many parts of this bill operate on the basis that they will apply to all employees and workplaces by default, requiring people to go before the Fair Work Commission to prove why something shouldn't apply to them, instead of having others needing to prove that it should.

Small-business owners are concerned about the complexity of these laws, and they fear large penalties should they get it wrong. It's the loss of flexibility in work arrangements which I think is one of the major issues with this bill. In my comments today I will focus on those sections which, of course, are of most concern to members of my electorate of Kooyong.

Climate change is the most demanding and important structural challenge to our economy. The actions that businesses will have to take to adapt to anthropogenic climate change, either of their own volition or in response to government policies, will require changes to historical work practices and changes in the way that they operate now. Climate change will change the nature of our markets and the nature of energy supply, and the ways in which energy is delivered will be transformed. Climate change will increase business costs, at least in the short to medium term. Climate change will require that markets change as new technologies come online. Businesses will have to develop new skills, and they'll have to deploy them in different and innovative ways. It's clear that technologies are going to continue to evolve rapidly. We're also seeing changes, though, in the social norms of workplaces, and those changes will change the demands that workers will make on the businesses for which they work. To help play their role in addressing climate change, businesses will need to change the way that they operate in response to each of these pressures. Businesses will need flexibility as they seek to be productive, competitive and profitable to take advantage of changes in markets, costs, skills, technologies and social norms so as to find better ways to serve the needs of their shareholders, their customers and their employees. Without that flexibility across the board, businesses will struggle to adapt how they operate, and changes may well be more costly and more distressing for them and may take longer.

For any given set of climate change policies and economic conditions, businesses will be less competitive, profitable and productive if they lack sufficient flexibility to be able to change and adapt. That flexibility has several dimensions. Firstly, businesses require the flexibility to adjust the size and nature of their workforces. Businesses already employ workers on a full-time, part-time and non-permanent basis. They rely on those non-permanent workers to adapt their operations to short-term economic or business fluctuations or to fulfil workplace needs without changing the size and nature of their permanent workforce. Secondly, they need flexibility of their working time. This is typically used to address short-term economic or business changes—for example, by increasing or reducing overtime. The third dimension is functional flexibility, which is the ability to change workplaces and practices in response to opportunities and threats that climate change poses. In each of these dimensions, business will always require the ability to change, and that should be exercised against a background of solid minimum wage requirements, bargaining over actual wages and employment conditions, and legislated protection of employees against the various forms of unfair treatment in the workplace.

In recent months I've met with a number of large- and small-business owners, industrial relations experts and constituents to discuss this bill and what it means for their workplaces. Many have expressed concerns that the proposed changes will limit job creation and reduce the flexibility of their workplaces. During the many disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, hospitality and other industries were dependent on the ability to flex up and down with casual staff. Had those industries not had that flexibility, many more businesses would have failed than was the case. Most recently I spoke with the owner of a large hospitality group, who gave me a number of examples of untenable changes to her workforce management which would result from the proposed legislation.

The government's industrial relations reform represents a significant opportunity for workplace reform in this country. Given the number of people engaged in gig and casual work, it is critical that the government gets this reform right. Many large business organisations and peak bodies have told us that they're still working through the hundreds of documents accompanying the bill in order to fully understand its implications, and many have expressed concerns regarding its complexity. There are some parts of this bill which are not controversial, and I would suggest that they should be carved out and passed immediately. I've welcomed the suggestion by senators Pocock and Lambie to split this legislation, creating four private senators' bills, so that crucial elements of this bill can be passed promptly.

Workplace safety should be the most important consideration for all employers. These separate measures will improve safety, they will protect vulnerable workers and they will support first responders in doing their jobs in times of national crisis and emergency. It's particularly crucial that we get them in place before what looks to be, unfortunately, a very challenging summer.

The measures that relate to post-traumatic stress disorder and compensation for first responders, expansion of the Asbestos Safety and Eradication Agency, improving protections for employees subjected to family and domestic violence, and clearer rules around small-business insolvencies should be passed immediately. Splitting the bill is a sensible approach which will ensure that the uncontroversial and broadly supported elements of this bill can be passed without delay.

In its 18 months, this Albanese government has exhibited a disappointing tendency to lump large and complex pieces of legislation into omnibus bills. Complex changes to the important aspects of our economy are, by this process, largely reduced to a binary choice, with very large pieces of legislation being put to a yes-or-no vote. It remains unclear to many in the community whether the government's proposed changes to regulations regarding casuals, labour hire, employee-like provisions, delegate rights and wage theft will actually result in the stronger productivity and better wage outcomes that have been predicted. The government is continuing to amend important aspects of this bill in response to pressure from industry and from this House. We shouldn't be designing a plane as it takes off.

This legislation is too important to get it wrong. I urge the government to pass the important safety elements of the bill, which do have broad support and which will immediately benefit vulnerable workers, while we await the results of the Senate inquiry into the more complex and contentious parts of this bill. At this time, though, and in this form, I'm not able to support this bill.

Ms SWANSON (Paterson) (20:57): Let's rewind the clock and take a look back to the year 2006. I do this because I really think it is important, in this debate, to contextualise the history of how we got to where we are today. I want to take the example of Sally, a mum in my electorate. It's 2006 and she has two children, aged five and nine. She's a single parent who works two jobs to make ends meet. She works at a cafe during the day, from 7 am through to around three, and she has also been able to pick up work in a reception job at a local dental clinic. She does this because she wants to keep her head above water without relying solely on Commonwealth assistance. Sally has worked in these two jobs for around 16 months as a diligent employee, and never takes time off. She is admired by her colleagues for her wonderful dedication. But, WorkChoices, which was introduced by the Howard government in 2005, is about to take a huge toll on Sally's livelihood and ability to earn for her family. Her daytime employer, the cafe, has asked her to sign an agreement stating that she must work every day from nine through to five. This adjustment to Sally's working pattern will severely impact her, as her other employer, the dental clinic, requires her to be in her reception role by 3:30. Thanks to WorkChoices and the Howard government, Sally must either sign the new agreement or face losing her job.

WorkChoices introduced Australian workplace agreements, known as AWAs, which were individual contracts between employers and employees. These agreements allowed employers to set employment terms and conditions directly with individual employees, bypassing collective agreements or awards. WorkChoices significantly impacted the landscape of employment in Australia for years through significantly reducing the role of industry awards in setting minimum employment conditions, including wages and working conditions. Also, employers had greater freedom to set their own employment conditions through AWAs. Simplification of the termination process made it easier for employers to dismiss employees. It introduced a no-fault termination system, allowing employers to terminate employment contracts without specific reasons.

Significantly, when we're talking about this, it feels like it wasn't that long ago, but in the next few years it'll be 20 years since those changes were made by the Howard government. How time flies! But it certainly didn't fly for people, like Sally, who were incredibly distressed by the AWAs, because they significantly limited unfair dismissal protections for employees, they lowered minimum wage protections, they reduced the role and influence of industrial tribunals in resolving workplace disputes and they extended working hours for employees with virtually no negotiation.

Sally wasn't the only one impacted. Casualisation of employees is rife in my electorate, with many in the education, manufacturing and mining industries, just to name a few, complaining to me that they are placed on perpetual contracts, which afford these employees no stability, no security and no voice to challenge their employment conditions. In the mining industry, it's known as 'trying to get a permanent shirt'. If you get a permanent shirt, it means that you are no longer employed under short-term contract job provider arrangements. Getting a permanent shirt means that you'll be employed by the pit, and many people seek those permanent shirts.

In 2009, under the leadership of the Australian Labor Party led by the former Prime Minister Kevin Rudd, the Fair Work Act was enacted by the Australian government. The Fair Work Act replaced the previous Workplace Relations Act of 1996 and introduced significant changes to Australia's industrial relations framework. It aimed to provide a more balanced approach to employment relationships, with a focus on workers' rights and protections, as well as ensuring fairness in the workplace.

As we have heard, in 2005 we had WorkChoices, while in 2009 we had the Fair Work Act. There are several ways in which the Fair Work Act helps people. The act sets out the National Employment Standards, referred to as the NES, which provide a minimum set of employment conditions for all Australian employees. These standards include provisions for maximum weekly hours, flexible work arrangements, parental leave, annual leave, personal and carers leave, public holidays and notice of termination. These standards ensure that all workers receive certain basic rights and entitlements.

There is also protection from unfair dismissal. The act includes provisions that protect employees from unfair dismissal. It establishes a framework for determining whether a dismissal was harsh, unjust or unreasonable and provides remedies to employees who have been unfairly dismissed. The Fair Work Commission also comes under and was established under the act. It serves as an independent body responsible for resolving workplace disputes, setting minimum wage rates and making decisions on a range of workplace matters. This commission helps ensure that workers have a forum to address employment related issues.

In terms of modern awards, the Fair Work Act introduced modern awards, which are industry specific employment standards that set out minimum pay rates, conditions and other entitlements for different industries and occupations. Modern awards help protect the rights of workers in specific sectors, ensuring they receive fair wages and working conditions. Collective bargaining was also important to the Fair Work Act. The act promotes collective bargaining by facilitating enterprise agreements between employers and employees. These agreements lead to improved wages and working conditions through negotiations between workers and employers. Also, flexible work arrangements mean that employees have a right to request flexible working arrangements under certain circumstances, such as caring for children or family members. The act helps people achieve a better work-life balance by supporting these requests.

Protection for vulnerable workers was also included in the Fair Work Act. It aims to protect vulnerable workers, such as migrant workers and young workers, from exploitation and unfair treatment in the workplace, helping to ensure that all workers, regardless of their background, are treated fairly. Workplace health and safety was also incorporated into the provisions related to workplace health and safety, helping to create safer work environments and reducing the risk of injury and accident on the job. It also has anti-discrimination provisions, including provisions to prohibit workplace discrimination on various grounds, including race, sex, age, disability and more. These provisions help create a fair and inclusive work environment. Regarding access to information, employees have the right to access information about their employment conditions such as pay rates, hours of work and leave entitlements. This transparency empowers workers to understand and assert their rights. In relation to compliance and enforcement, the Fair Work Act includes mechanisms for enforcing its provisions, including penalties for non-complying employers. This helps ensure that employers adhere to their legal obligations.

In summary, the Fair Work Act 2009 helps people by establishing a framework that provides basic employment standards, protects workers' rights and ensures a fair and balanced employment relationship between employers and employees. It seeks to create more equitable and just workplaces for all Australians.

I stand before you today to address a pressing issue that affects every corner of our society—the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill. That's what we're really talking about tonight, but I felt it absolutely necessary to provide a framework of history so that people can understand why these changes are necessary and how this evolution has taken place since the Howard years. I want to take this opportunity to explore the significance of the bill, its key provisions and why it's crucial for our nation's future. The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill—remembering that we're amending legislation that was brought in by the Rudd government—is a milestone in our journey towards achieving fair and decent working conditions for all Australians. It comes at a time when the labour landscape is evolving rapidly, with the rise of the gig economy, changing employer and employee relationships, again, and growing concerns about income inequality. This bill is not just a piece of legislation; it's a beacon of hope for workers who have been marginalised and exploited due to gaps in our existing labour laws.

To fully appreciate the importance of this bill we must first understand the context in which it's being proposed. Our Fair Work Act, enacted in 2009, was a significant step forward in protecting workers' rights and promoting industrial harmony. However, over the years, certain gaps and ambiguities have emerged, allowing unscrupulous employers to exploit these loopholes at the expense of their employees. One of the primary challenges this bill seeks to address is the impact of the gig economy on workers' rights. The gig economy has brought flexibility to the labour market, but it has also given rise to precarious employment conditions. Many gig workers are classified as independent contractors rather than employees, depriving them of fundamental protections such as a minimum wage, paid leave and unfair dismissal rights.

Let's go back to Sally, who I was talking about at the beginning. She was working at the cafe. Under the Fair Work legislation, she was to receive a certain amount of standards, even though she had signed the workplace agreement—the AWA. If she was delivering food from the cafe in the gig economy, she would not be receiving very much security at all. That's where we've gone in those years since 2005 and then 2009. So here we are, in 2023, trying to really bolster the protections and drag the legislation into the current landscape of employment in Australia.

The first key provision of this bill is the definition of employment status. The bill provides a clearer definition of employee and independent contractor status, leaving no room for ambiguity. This will prevent employers from misclassifying workers to avoid their legal obligations. It also changes entitlements through minimum wage protections. All workers, regardless of their employment status, will be entitled to a minimum wage that reflects the cost of living. This provision is vital in ensuring that no-one is forced to live in poverty due to their work.

The bill guarantees paid leave entitlements for all workers, including sick leave, annual leave and parental leave. No-one should have to choose between their health or their family and their job. It strengthens the unfair dismissal protections, making it more difficult for employers to terminate employees unfairly, without proper justification. The bill promotes collective bargaining by simplifying the process for workers to join unions and negotiate for better wages and working conditions.

To combat wage theft, the bill introduces stringent penalties for employers who underpay their workers or fail to provide entitlements. I want to say that, in this bill, we're not looking to penalise employers who make honest mistakes. We all know that payroll can be exceptionally complicated. It's often a whole world of pain for employers, in its own right. So, where someone has made a mistake, genuinely and honestly, there will be a way to rectify that. Also, we're talking about businesses with over 15 employees. A small business is a business with 15 employees or under, and I think that's a really important point to make in this.

The reason this bill matters is that the proposed changes will result in reducing income inequality. The widening income gap in Australia is a pressing concern, and I do have a fear at the moment that we have a bit of a two-speed economy running. I think that this bill is going to be a crucial step towards reducing income inequality by ensuring that all workers are paid more fairly for their labour. It's going to protect vulnerable workers, including those in the gig economy, who often have very little bargaining power. It's going to empower them by extending basic labour rights and creating a more level playing field, and it's further going to promote economic stability. Fair and equitable working conditions are essential not only for individual wellbeing but also for economic stability, and—dare I say it—also for community. People need to know when they're going to work, when they're going to be able to look after their children, how they can coordinate with their friends and family for child care and how their lives are going to go. In my experience of life, the more you can plan or at least have a clue about where you're going to be and what you're going to be doing, it does make it a lot easier to live and see out the logistics of life, as we like to call it in our family.

This bill is determined to enhance social cohesion. A fair work environment fosters social cohesion by reducing resentment and inequality in our society. It sends the message that we value and respect the contribution of all workers, regardless of their job type or employment status. I've always believed that a great test of character when you're with someone is how they treat children, animals and those that serve them. So, in this bill, I hope that those that serve us and keep our economy going will have a better sense of fairness and will feel valued. At the end of the day, employers are winners as well, because they foster that sense of belonging to a business. It fosters loyalty. In that sense, productivity and many other gains can be made. I fully support this bill and recommend its passing to the House.

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (21:12): I would like, before I commence speaking to the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023, to say: we started in this chamber over 12 hours ago—no, sorry; over nine hours ago. See, I'm already delirious and tired! You have to question why we had to cancel a sitting week and why we could not have worked through this bill in an orderly fashion at an orderly time, rather than having people at quarter past nine, until 10.30 tonight, giving their speeches. However, I digress.

In speaking on this bill, one could be forgiven for having a sense of deja vu with this legislation, referring not to the specifics of the legislation but rather to the tactics that have been employed. For all the ideological differences between the major parties, they both, when in government, have synonymous form for trying to pass contentious legislation by intentionally bundling everything together and putting it in the same bill—omnibus bills. And here we are again. Before us, we have a very complex and overreaching bill with some very draconian measures for both employers and workers. The government, conscious of this, is using the good elements, such as stronger protections against discrimination and for people subject to family and domestic violence, as leverage to obtain support for a raft of what I think are very bad and somewhat dangerous changes. This approach by successive governments is disingenuous, and the Australian public are, I think, sick and tired of political point scoring through wedge politics of this nature.

We had the opportunity this week, just yesterday, to pass four bills that were supported in the other place, each of which were a mirror of the non-contentious components of this bill. And yet these bills were not supported by the government. I'd like to say I was surprised; I think I was just disappointed.

What does this tell us? It tells us that the government is aware that it does not have community, employee, employer or political support for this bill in its entirety and that the only way it believes it will secure the passage of this bill is to combine the contentious provisions with the non-contentious provisions. Good policy stands on its own merit and should not be leveraged to pursue ideological commitments. Good policy stems from objectifiable needs—for example, a problem that requires addressing, or systemic failures in economic, social and environmental matters that may benefit from legislative intervention. It is in this context that I wish to address the schedules in this bill.

Schedule 1 proposes substantial changes to casual employment, including changes to the definition of a casual. I ask the question: why is there a need for change? According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the percentage of casually employed people in August 2022 was 23.5 per cent. In August 1997 it was around 23.5 per cent. It's the same. Why do we need to change this? Why is there such urgency? In a quarter of a century, the level of casualisation in the workforce has remained the same, and this is despite monumental changes in the industry, technology and employment sectors. What is the problem that we're trying to fix here? If this bill passes we regress from a current and well-understood definition of what a casual employee is to a more complex and confusing definition that has at least 12 detailed, yet ambiguous, tests. This will lead to an increase in disputes and costs, and will most likely result in employers not engaging casual workers.

I wonder if there's a problem with the number of casual workers in the workforce or if there's a problem with trade union membership, which has been in a serious decline over the same period—from 32 per cent in 1997 to around 12 per cent in 2022. Unions appear to be the only beneficiaries that I can see associated with these changes. More contentiously, the bill proposes significant changes to the employment of casuals. We currently have pathways for casuals to move to permanent employment. Casual loadings and rostering flexibility suit many workers and, in some cases, are necessary for their home, study and work-life balance. However, this bill will take away that flexibility and will reduce their take-home pay at a time when the cost of living is at an all-time high. It is a perverse outcome which is creating a problem rather than fixing one, if the premise of the problem is accepted. This change will affect thousands of workers who have no issue with their current arrangements. For example, one of my children chooses to work as a casual and has regularity in her shifts. It suits her and it suits her employer. Despite this mutually-convenient working arrangement, this proposal requires changes that are not suitable to either party. How on earth is that good policy? It gets worse, though. If an employer incorrectly engages an employee as a casual and then, according to the myriad ambiguous tests proposed, they are by definition a permanent worker, that employer may be fined.

Business already operates in a complex and confusing workplace relations environment. We should be simplifying this, not making it more complex. It is a consequence of the existing and increasing complexity of the industrial relations system that I move my second reading amendments. I move:
That all words after "reading" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"(1) is concerned that the industrial legislative landscape is already complex and difficult for small business employers to navigate;
(2) notes that the legislation imposes even more onerous requirements for small business employers while at the same time taking away employee rights; and
(3) calls for the establishment of an authoritative body in order to:
(a) provide no cost unambiguous advice to employers in relation to the interpretation of awards, enterprise agreements and the Fair Work Act; and
(b) provide protection for employers who have acted on the advice provided".

While a very small number of employers may knowingly act in breach of their legal obligations, the vast majority of employers strive to act in accordance with their legislative requirements. If government is going to impose penalties for employers that mistakenly do not comply with confusing industrial laws then they need to provide a service that provides employers with unequivocal advice. My amendment seeks the establishment of an authoritative body to do exactly that.

There are parts of schedule 1 that I support, such as the small business redundancy exemption, enabling multiple franchises to access a single-enterprise stream, transitioning from multiple enterprise agreements and models terms in parts 2 to 5. Part 6 of schedule 1—closing the labour hire loophole is purported by the government to address circumstances where labour hire is used to undercut wages that would otherwise apply to an existing enterprise agreement.
