However, under the proposed amendments, it doesn't just apply to labour hire and there is no requirement for any evidence that the host has used labour hire for the purpose of undercutting wages. Instead, unions may argue that a host enterprise agreement is not satisfactory and simply apply for an alternative agreement to become the obligation that a labour hire company must meet. The whole purpose of enterprise bargaining is based on the principle that different employers employing workers to perform similar work may have different pay and conditions. If the government truly wants same job, same pay outcomes, then why have enterprise agreements at all? These amendments are completely at odds with the concept of enterprise bargaining, and we may as well go back to the simpler times with single awards.

Part 7 prescribes protections and additional rights to workplace delegates. Again, the government has failed to articulate the problem. Workplace delegates already have protections and rights enshrined in legislation and, indeed, enterprise agreements. Of particular concern is the ability of unions to unilaterally determine how many delegates should be appointed in each workplace and how much time off is necessary for training. We are pushing employers to the brink with an endless barrage of complex legislative impositions with increased penalties for noncompliance, while at the same time reducing their capacity to run their own businesses. At what point do employers simply say, 'This is too hard,' and close their doors or go offshore or go completely to mechanisation?

I resolutely support part 8—strengthening protections against discrimination. No person should be disadvantaged or discriminated against, especially when they experience family and domestic violence. Again, I remind you, we could have had that very important provision through this House yesterday.

Part 10 provides for additional circumstances where a union may obtain an exemption from the notice of intent to enter a workplace. While I support the first circumstance, where there is a realisable risk that an entry notice might result in the destruction, concealment or alteration of relevant evidence, I do not support the second circumstance, based on a suspected contravention. Most underpayments occur by mistake and are due to the overly complex industrial laws, which make it extremely difficult to determine the actual award rate of pay that an employer must assign to an employee. Reducing the complexity of the industrial system, not emboldening unions with more power, will reduce the incidence of underpayment.

A speaking allocation of 15 minutes is a challenge when debating extensive legislation such as this—as, again, is doing it at this hour of the evening. Accordingly, I wish to use the remainder of my time on schedule 1, part 16, noting that there is so much to this bill that I will not get to. Firstly, aggregating platform or gig work and road transport in the same part is unnecessarily confusing; they should have been included in separate parts of the bill. My comments relate specifically to platform contract work. Secondly, I ask again: what is the problem the government seeks to fix? Is it the safety of gig workers? It hasn't achieved that. Is it a fair contract price or financial reward for services? It has failed to provide a convincing argument. The government's own explanatory memorandum uses calculations to determine the hourly wage gap between relevant awards and average hourly earnings of digital platform workers. The gap for a food delivery driver is $3.09 per hour and $3.95 per hour for a rideshare contractor, rounded up to $4.10 per hour, assuming proportionate increases to the award and platform earnings between 2019 and 2023. Four dollars and 10 cents per hour works out to be around 13 to 15 per cent of the hourly rate and, in fairness, it does appear to be a large gap. However, the analysis does not consider the tax concessions of owning and operating your own business, including the ability to write off assets such as vehicles, computers and phones, or the operational costs associated with the activity. This would lead to a closer, or possibly higher, hourly rate after tax.

Importantly, the analysis also fails to properly consider the non-financial benefits, which include flexibility of working hours and being your own boss. These have a value, even if they can't be quantified in an hourly rate. I recently received correspondence from a courier driver who also works around 12 hours per week with Uber and has done so for around five years. The gentleman—I'll call him John—succinctly summed up the proposed changes. He said:
Wanting to reform the gig economy when we all signed up for it—no one forced us to sign up—is ludicrous.

John explains that he drives for Uber to help pay bills and, while confident he could find another job to supplement his income, he chooses to drive for Uber as it provides a flexible way for him to earn extra income. John is one of tens of thousands of drivers who earn extra income this way. These proposed changes will increase costs to consumers, which will result in less demand and, ultimately, less money for the drivers. The restaurant trade in cities that have increased employment for award workers will experience a decrease in trade. The government analysis reports that future economic impact, in the form of increased wages, is more than $400 million per year. It hasn't calculated the economic cost of flow-on effects to the multitude of businesses that now rely on delivery and other related services.

If the government was to separate this bill, there are many parts that I would support; however, I cannot support this bill in its current form, as it is being pushed through in its entirety. The government has failed to provide a convincing argument for these reforms, and I do not wish to see hardworking Australians, whether they are business owners, small businesses, which are the backbone of this nation, or employees, have their liberties and earning capacity diminished. I move:
That all words after "reading" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"(1) is concerned that the industrial legislative landscape is already complex and difficult for small business employers to navigate;
(2) notes that the legislation imposes even more onerous requirements for small business employers while at the same time taking away employee rights; and
(3) calls for the establishment of an authoritative body in order to:
(a) provide no cost unambiguous advice to employers in relation to the interpretation of awards, enterprise agreements and the Fair Work Act; and
(b) provide protection for employers who have acted on the advice provided".

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Ms Claydon ): Is the amendment seconded?
Mr Wilkie: I second the amendment moved by the member for Mayo and, of course, I reserve my right to speak.

Ms LAWRENCE (Hasluck) (21:27): Why are we debating the closing of loopholes? The coalition presided over the years of the digital transformation of workplaces, where the very nature of work and the employee-employer relationship fundamentally changed, and they did nothing to uphold the rights of workers. They oversaw the erosion of minimum standards, the erosion of the right to bargain, the erosion of safety nets and the erosion of the value of enterprise agreements. Perhaps many opposite would chalk up that list as wins, but it is an appalling attack on the essence of what it means to be Australian. It is an attack on the fair go. It's an attack on workers who were subject to the deliberate suppression of their wages for a decade, on workers stuck in precarious casual work, on gig workers and on labour hire workers—the workers who went backwards under the previous government. Those workers are all glad now that they have an ally in this government, a government that understands what workers want and need and a government that has their back.

The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023 provides clear pathways for casuals to transition to permanent work, ensures protections for gig economy workers, closes the labour hire loophole and criminalises wage theft.

The over-casualisation and the normalisation of permanent casuals is making it harder for individuals and families to build and plan for their future. Let's not be lulled into thinking casual work is limited to supermarket checkout workers, corner delis or pulling beers on a Saturday night. University lecturers, aged-care workers, bank tellers, miners, truck drivers, people working in the media and warehouse workers—casual work exists across all sectors and affects the people we rely on to keep our economy and our society pumping. These casual workers are trying to support families, run households, pay rent, pay their bills and secure a mortgage, and the insecurity of casual work affects their capacity to do so. Employers, meanwhile, are enjoying the benefits of stable and reliable rosters by treating casuals as permanent workers without having to provide any job security in return. It is a loophole that needs to be closed.

It's important to reiterate that no casual will be forced to lose their loading; no casual will be forced to become a permanent employee. This will be an employee choice. But, for those who do want that security and are being rostered as though they are permanent, security is now within sight. It is surely difficult to oppose this new pathway to conversion, a measure simply designed to allow the truth of a situation to shine through and to take effect.

The same commitment to truth underpins the legislation addressing the dearth of protections currently in place for workers in the gig economy—workers who work through digital labour platforms in areas such as food delivery, rideshare and the care economy. Currently, if you're classified as an employee, you have a whole raft of rights and entitlements, including minimum rates of pay, sick leave and annual leave. If, like the vast majority of gig economy workers, you are not classified as an employee, those rights, as Minister Burke has said, fall off a cliff. This bill allows for the flexibility that many workers enjoy as a feature of this technology without leaving them completely exposed and without protection.

My colleague the member for Burt referred in his speech to the tragic death of food delivery driver Burak Dogan, whose uncle I met here at the house just a few months ago. Uber Eats claimed food delivery driver Burak Dogan wasn't working for them when he went under a truck in April 2020, despite his phone receiving job requests from Uber Eats at the exact time of his death and afterwards as he lay dead on the road. Under this bill, workers like Burak will no longer fall through the cracks.

Under this bill, workers will also receive the same pay for the same job. The labour hire loophole is a back-door way for unscrupulous employers to deny workers the agreed pay and conditions enjoyed by colleagues doing the exact same job. Let's pause there for a moment to reflect on the temerity of this behaviour. An employer sits at the bargaining table with their workers, and together in good faith they negotiate a set of wages and conditions that are agreeable to all parties. Why then should labour hire workers, when they are brought in to cover seasonal or surge periods, be paid less than the already agreed minimum wage for that job? They shouldn't. It's a loophole, and we're closing it.

It should not be legal to deliberately undercut agreements, and it should certainly not be legal to deliberately underpay workers. It is rightly against the law to steal from the cash register, and soon it will be against the law to steal wages from workers. That is why we are criminalising wage theft. Much like the proliferation of casualisation, wage theft is not limited to low-skill or entry-level jobs. University tutors have found themselves in this situation.

Many are aware of the 7-Eleven wage theft case—the business model built on the systemic theft of wages, doctored time sheets, threats of deportation, and workers taking home sometimes half of their hourly rate. It was disgusting and it was rightly exposed, and the company is now paying a hefty price through civil suits.

Recently a survey of young members was conducted by a union in Western Australia. This survey covered a litany of workplace issues, including bullying, discrimination, harassment, burnout, roster compliance, payments, mandatory training and, saliently, wage theft. This wasn't the shopkeepers union, the construction union or the hospitality union. It was the Australian Medical Association. In Victoria, in August, the Federal Court found in favour of young Melbourne doctor Gaby Bolton in a systemic wage theft class action. There are a further nine class actions on foot across the country, concerning 15 health services.
Wage-thieving employers do not discriminate. From service stations to surgeries, wage theft is insidious wherever and whenever it occurs. We are criminalising wage theft. Theft is theft.

I have read and heard a few of the speeches of those opposite on this bill. Please correct me if I slip and refer to the 'member for Westacott', but the coalition have been reading a little too closely from the Business Council song sheet on this one.

Members opposite will need to explain to their constituents why they won't act on wage theft, won't close loopholes, won't protect gig workers and won't give casuals a pathway to security. Union delegates speak to these workers every day. One of the differences between our side and those opposite is that we have the benefit of hearing from unions and their members on a regular basis. We hear their stories. We know what they face in their workplaces every day of the week because they tell us.

I acknowledge the member for Paterson, who has been a strong advocate for her community on this bill. I also acknowledge the member for Kennedy, who is a proud union member. I expect he will support the bill because he understands these issues very well and is passionate about them.

I urge members opposite to engage with unions and their members, to invite them into their offices and to hear firsthand their stories and understand better the needs of Australian workers. The limited gene pool of the IPA and the Business Council cannot provide them that perspective. It is important for a party to be able to bring a range of views and experiences to each and every piece of legislation in this place.

The members for New England and Longman in their contributions on this bill dragged out that lazy old line that ALP members don't know anything about running a business. We do have our fair share of lawyers, academics and doctors, and maybe they also run businesses. But I know I have a business. The member for Hunter has a business. The members for Tangney, Bennelong and Parramatta have had businesses. In the other place, my friend Senator Sterle and Minister Farrell have had businesses. I'm sure I'm just scratching the surface. So I think that the members for New England and Longman might want to need to drag themselves out of whichever century they are living in and realise that the modern Labor caucus is not just gender diverse and culturally diverse; we are also diverse in backgrounds and experiences. We know how to run businesses, and we know when a business is being run in a way that is unfair to workers.

The member for Moncrieff, a little oddly, wants to oppose the bill on the basis of choice and flexibility. She says choice and flexibility are the bedrock of the Liberal Party. I always smile in a tight-lipped sort of way when I hear the Liberal Party talk about choice. They support choice, but not for everyone, though—just for those who can pay for it. The Liberal mantra of choice is built upon a sedimentary bedrock of people who don't have choice, who can't choose, who can't afford to choose. It's an affront to hear choice raised as an attack on a bill designed to provide those people, ordinary workers, with fair and just pay and conditions so they don't have to choose the unfair and only option available to them.

Nothing in this bill will get in the way of wealthy people expressing choice. Nothing in this bill will get in the way of businesses choosing to arrange their affairs as they wish unless what they are choosing is to exploit workers. The use of labour hire companies is a case in point. This bill won't prevent any business from using a labour hire company if they wish to. The ethical and well-run businesses will continue to do exactly that without blinking. If, however, what is really happening is that the business is choosing to do this merely in order to avoid its obligations to workers and pay less than the agreed rates then that poor conduct is captured.

The member for Page offered another faraway land of Oz. He said we don't need this legislation because, as far as he can tell, people look after their staff. That was quite a broad and risky statement I thought. Here in the real world some people don't look after their staff, and this legislation will help to deal with that. Not content with saying that, the member for Page went further out on a limb and stated that we have an award system and minimum rates of pay so people aren't abused or exploited. I mean, really? I am glad, of course, that the member for Page appreciates the fruits of the labours of the great Australian trade union movement, but the member must have missed the minister's speech where he reminded us that, for those workers that this bill seeks to assist, minimum standards in awards and agreements are often no more than words on a page.
In vivid contrast, my friend the member for Werriwa referred saliently to article 23 of the UN Declaration of Human Rights. It's worth repeating:
2. Everyone, without any discrimination, has the right to equal pay for equal work.

3. Everyone who works has the right to just and favourable remuneration ensuring for himself and his family an existence worthy of human dignity, and supplemented, if necessary, by other means of social protection.
This bill is another firm and necessary step towards that lofty, reasonable and worthwhile goal.

Members opposite should be supporting this legislation. They aren't, but they should. They know that the ills this legislation is aimed at are just rorts. As Minister Burke stated on Monday, the opposition had every opportunity to introduce legislation in relation to these matters over many years and did nothing. I hope that every worker in Hasluck, and every worker across Australia, takes a good, hard look at those members opposite who vote no to this legislation. I still hope that some may cross the floor and vote in the interests of Australian workers. Liberal and National members will be voting no to properly defining casual employees because they don't care that some workers are disadvantaged by the fiction that employment is casual. The Liberal and National members will vote no to drawing a clearer line between employees and independent contractors because they don't care if some workers lose out on conditions and benefits in unfair circumstances. The Liberal and National members will vote no to the principle of 'same work, same pay' because they don't have sufficient respect for wage earners. The Liberal and National members will vote no to the criminalisation of wage theft. I don't know how they can do that, but there you go. The Liberal and National members will vote no to minimum standards for gig workers and transport workers because they haven't got the slightest idea what minimum standards are.

The 'no-alition' will vote no to these fair and necessary changes to the law to close the loopholes that currently allow some workers to be left behind. But the work done by those workers is no less important than anyone else's, and the Albanese government has pledged that we will leave no-one behind. This government is a government of conviction, and this bill is a necessary step in fulfilling that commitment. I commend the minister for his ongoing work to ensure that all workers fairly share in the fruits of their shared labour, and I support the bill.

Ms SPENDER (Wentworth) (21:41): The debate over the Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023 is a further reminder that industrial relations is one of the great fissures in Australian politics. IR is a policy space which resembles nothing more than a decades long trench war where each side invests huge amounts of time, energy and money contesting the same ground each generation. Yet we are all broadly on the same page when it comes to the outcomes we're seeking for this country. We all want to build on the prosperity that Australians currently enjoy and ensure that the next generation enjoys a quality of life which is equal to our own and preferably better.

We broadly agree on what is needed to get there. We need competitive markets to drive down costs and drive up the quality of goods and services we consume. We need competitive and productive labour markets to drive up the wages Australians receive for their work. We need education, health care and social security systems to ensure that Australians are able to make the most of their lives. And, of course, we need an effective government to make this all work.

The problem we face and the reason that our quality of life is not growing as it once was is that we have failed to nurture the drivers of a better life. Product markets are too concentrated and not as competitive as they could be. Labour markets are not delivering the productivity growth needed to drive up wages. Our education, health and social security systems are not delivering for students, patients or those who rely on essential public services. This is the problem we should be considering with every bill that comes through parliament.

This is an important issue at all times—how do we continue to build on the prosperity of this country? But this is also an urgent consideration for this parliament. The OECD released the information, just last week, that Australia has recorded the biggest income decline in the developed world in the last year. If that doesn't give this parliament pause for thought about how every single piece of legislation that we put through contributes to overall living standards for all Australians then I'm not sure what will. We should be asking whether this bill and any other bill is making a constructive contribution to delivering a better quality of life to Australians both now and in the future. This is the frame through I which I looked at this industrial relations bill. Will it help to deliver a better quality of life? Will it improve labour market outcomes so that workers are better off in the short term as well as—and most importantly—in the long term. I think that is an important distinction to raise, because there can be shifts in the short term. We can look at the pie and divide it up differently between workers and capital, and workers and company profits. That is an option in policy. But the bigger question, the ultimate driver of the wages of people in this country, which I think is what this bill is ultimately about, is about the long term. As the Productivity Commissioner and many others have demonstrated, real growth in wages long term is dependent on productivity, and that is what we need to drive through this and many other pieces of legislation.

We have to consider what would drive productivity, particularly from an IR point of view. Thankfully, the Productivity Commission has repeatedly considered this question and its findings are abundantly clear. Volume 7 of the Advancing Prosperity report spelled out what is needed. It argued we need greater cooperation between employers and employees, 'more flexibility and efficiency' in the award system and more focus on the 'mutual benefits and productivity gains' in enterprise bargaining within a broader ethical framework of workplace fairness. It also made the point, which I think is well understood outside this parliament but often forgotten inside, that both employers and employees have strong incentives to realise productivity gains. Employers benefit because more productive employees deliver more value and more profit for the business, and employees benefit because labour productivity is closely tied to real wages, so the rewards from cooperation, flexibility, efficiency and productivity ultimately flow into workers in the form of higher wages and a better quality of life. So the question before us on this bill is whether this bill makes the changes that are needed and whether it will drive better productivity, and ultimately wages, for individuals.

I would like to also make the point that IR should also consider workers' protections and worker fairness. Probably the merits of this bill are where there are some supports for worker protection and worker fairness. But I also want to make the point that, when you look at worker protections, worker fairness and how you drive all those pieces, you must also look at this broader piece on productivity, because you can close every last loophole that any business might try and exploit. I take the principle of trying to close loopholes where bad actors are exploiting them, but there is a cost. This country is overburdened by regulation, and, if you continue to burden the businesses with over- or complex regulation, there is a cost on productivity, which is ultimately a cost borne by workers in the form of lower wages. So every question, every legitimate push, for worker protection has to also consider what are the burdens put on the business and is that an appropriate cost? I think in many cases in relation to this bill it is not.

What I'd like to do is now talk to some of the key points of the bill, and let's start with casual workers. My real concern is that the changes in this bill will create considerable legal uncertainty for businesses. The uncertainty that it will start to create is whether a person who has been engaged is a casual worker, which may change over time even without the discussion or even the direct involvement of the employer or the employee and will also create uncertainty at the point of employment. Quite subjective factors will determine the classification of an employee, and it is conceivable that some casual employees will be later found to be permanent employees by Fair Work even if this is contrary to what the casual employee actually wants, and then the employer may be liable for penalties. So this is a situation, because of the changes to the definition of casual employees—moving away from the contract defining whether a person is a casual to a long list of potential factors to determine—means that a person who would like to be a casual may find that, perhaps through a union or others, they are found not to be a casual and they can't continue to be a casual even if that is what they are seeking. I think that creates uncertainty for the business, but it is also a poor outcome for the employee. And I think the inevitable conclusion of this uncertainty is that businesses will shy away from engaging and retaining casual staff. It may be that the government's intention is to do this because it believes permanent employment is preferable because it contains or conveys certain benefits and security to the employee.

We should also acknowledge there are trade-offs here. One of the trade-offs is flexibility, which is largely valued by a large number of employers and employees and undoubtedly yields productivity outcomes that directly benefit both parties. Another trade-off is that not all casual work will be readily converted to permanent work. By reducing the illegal availability of casual work, some jobs will become permanent but others will simply cease to exist. And e61 demonstrated that, in previous situations where there was a reduction in flexibility of work, companies, in some of their choices, decided to invest more in capital than in labour; they substituted out of having workers and into the automation you now see in supermarkets. This is a real choice for companies and a choice that I think will increasingly be made with a push to reduce flexibility in the workplace. I think this is clearly to the detriment of both parties, particularly because casual employment is often how people first enter the workplace as young people on their first job, or if they are returning to work or if they are trying to balance caring responsibilities. That is where casual work is often really valued by employees. If we reduce the opportunities for casual work, we are going to have the unintended consequence of stopping some of the most vulnerable people in Australia being able to access the jobs that give them a really important start in their careers.

I'm also concerned about the complexity—I talked earlier about complexity—about the additional pathways to transforming from a casual employee to a permanent employee. I thoroughly support that casual employees should have the right in the appropriate circumstances to move to being permanent employees. I've run businesses where I've done that, and done that extremely proudly; I'm very proud to have done that. But to have multiple ways that that can be done, and to do that after six months, when many businesses in this country are seasonal and have a much stronger seasonal summer trade than a winter trade, is problematic. We should make it simpler for the employees and the employer to convert to casuals and not provide additional layers but work out how to provide one pathway from being a casual to being a permanent employee that meets all the requirements and is done after 12 months.

I'm also concerned about the labour hire provisions. I would say to many in the Labor Party who have spoken on this bill that there are bad actors and legitimate concerns about labour hire. But with such a broad-ranging bill with such broad powers, the concern is that moving beyond the aviation and mining sector—which it feels very much like these provisions are aimed at—is going to regulate the entire workplace, to deal with two sectors. Again, this provides uncertainty and also a burden to the rest of the economy at a time where I honestly don't believe we should be providing those sorts of concerns and burdens to the economy. I think it will also create substantial legal uncertainty, and when you have legal uncertainty businesses don't invest—and that is extremely problematic.

We look at the gig economy changes. I applaud the government for bringing the gig economy to the parliament and saying we should have minimum standards; I thoroughly agree. We should have minimum standards for gig economy workers because I think those protections are appropriate. However, it is the extent of these standards and the ambiguity of these standards which means that I think there will be a significant loss of opportunity for gig economy workers as well as an increasing burden on the businesses, which can have a chilling effect on the platform workers.

One of the aspects of the gig economy work which I think is also concerning is the amount of uncertainty which is tied into what the Fair Work Commission will do, because so much of this bill is effectively a referral to the Fair Work Commission. I respect the Fair Work Commission, but, when businesses want to start and change and evolve, constantly having to go back to the Fair Work Commission, if you're trying to start or change a business, creates uncertainty and stops innovation which is so critical to the Australian economy going forward.

Turning back to the gig economy work, there are a number of concerns. The Fair Work Commission may make overarching decisions that may not be tailored to the platform or the workers they are driven around. Some orders may even apply to platforms who have not participated in the standard setting process.

My concern, when we come back to the beginning, is that productivity gains occur when employers and workers come together and ask, 'How can we work more productively together?' I'm concerned about how this sort of work will drive those productivity gains. At the same time, I'm concerned that the digital platforms can essentially buy their way out of labour market regulation by cutting a deal with a union, even if their workplace is not unionised. Allowing individuals or organisations to avoid their legal obligations by contracting with a third party is a dangerous precedent to set.

Finally, I'd like to make a broader point on the legislation, which is that a lot of this legislation comes down to regulation and ministerial powers. Ministerial powers, to the extent that they are in this bill, are a dangerous way to drive labour market regulation. Businesses want certainty and clarity, which enable them to make investment decisions.

My concern with this bill, which has been outlined this week by many others, is that there are some measures that should go ahead straightaway, like ensuring that redundancy for small businesses is not exploited by large businesses downsizing. The Senate has already sent a number of bills to this House that could be passed straightaway and would make a difference to workers' lives and protections. There are a number of elements of this bill that, taken individually and tailored, would strike the right balance between worker protections and ensuring the productivity of the economy. However, I'm afraid the government has gone too far in the extent to which it is trying to overregulate the market and prevent the flexibility that is so important to our economy. At this stage, I won't be supporting this bill without amendment.

Mr ZAPPIA (Makin) (21:56): The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023 stops the exploitation of some of the country's lowest paid workers, and it does that by closing loopholes that currently allow that exploitation. If the legislation is not perfect, I say this: the current system is far from perfect as well. Indeed, the current system needs many changes. When I read the legislation, I note that there are over 20 different areas of loopholes that are currently being exploited by unethical employers—not by all; I accept that there are many good employers out there. I suspect that the good employers are not fearful of this legislation. I don't believe the good employers are the ones who are opposing this legislation.

The people who are going to be protected by this legislation are people who, in my view, are in a desperate situation where they need to do whatever work is available to them at whatever rates are made available for them and who, more likely than not, are not in any position to bargain, negotiate or, in many cases, even understand what their rights ought to be. The arguments I have heard from those opposite, in respect to this legislation, are the same arguments that I hear time and time again whenever we deal with industrial relations reforms in this parliament. I suspect they are the same arguments that we've been having for the last hundred years or so. Over those hundred years, there have been incredible improvements in terms of fairness for the people who work throughout this country, but I suspect that all along the way the argument of fairness has been opposed by the big employers of this country, and many others for that matter.

I also accept that some of the workers who are going to be affected by this legislation are subcontractors, farmers and transport operators who themselves are often also employers and who, in turn, are being exploited by bigger businesses. We are seeing that right now in the dairy industry where both the dairy farmers, whom I would credit as being employers in their own right, and the dairy workers are being exploited by the very profitable multinationals. I spoke a farmer not long ago—not a dairy farmer but a horticultural farmer—who is actually a big farmer that employs a lot of people and who had to literally cut a contract with one of the major supermarket chains because he was being exploited to the point where he couldn't make ends meet, and that in turn affected obviously the people he employed. So I accept that there will be employers who are also, in their own right, workers that are currently being exploited.

The exploitation of workers is not new, and slavery in the past was an extreme example of that. However, in modern society, and since the abolition of slavery, the exploitation of workers has been a common trait amongst the ruling class throughout the world for decades. It's not just here in Australia. It's commonly used throughout the world. It continues today across the world, including here in Australia, where hard-won work conditions and fair remuneration are now being slowly eroded under the pretentious philosophy of freedom of choice and flexibility. Those two terms that I hear so often, 'flexibility' and 'freedom of choice', are nothing more than a way to push people into a situation where they have no choice but to work under those conditions. It's a philosophy that has managed to convert too many previously secure jobs into insecure underpaid work, and the jobs are all too often being carried out by unskilled workers from overseas countries, sometimes as new migrants or on temporary or student visas, who are in desperate financial need. These are some of the most vulnerable people who, as I said earlier, often don't even know what their rights are.

Yes, it is true that in some cases the flexibility is a preferred voluntary choice, but in most cases it is not. It is the only choice. I've heard members opposite talking about that flexibility, and, yes, I accept that in some cases it absolutely is a choice of the worker, but in too many cases it's not. Even if it is a choice, it should always be remunerated at a fair level of income, and that's not happening either. It is clear that those who, over a decade ago, drove the failed WorkChoices legislation have never given up. What they've done is simply change their tactics and pursue alternative methods of exploiting workers, with a common practice being to transition workers from permanent employees to self-employed subcontractors, and I have seen that time and time again. In doing so, they wash their hands of fair pay rates, they wash their hands of holiday and sick leave, and they wash their hands of long service leave and income security. In more recent times, the use of labour hire firms, who in turn allow employers to shirk their responsibility, has become all too common.

A few weeks ago, I visited workers at the Ingham's poultry processing factory at Bolivar, just north of Adelaide, where the workers were striking for better pay and better conditions. Ingham's workers do physically demanding production line work that results in higher rates of repetitive stress injuries. In 2021, one worker was killed in a preventable workplace accident, and I stress the word preventable. By its very nature, the work is unpleasant and demanding, with even toilet breaks being timed. Ingham's is the most profitable poultry processing company in the southern hemisphere. The workers there were seeking a modest pay rise for their average $25 an hour pay rate. After five days of striking, they won a modest pay rise over several years and, importantly, some better conditions, including rights for casuals to convert to permanency. Again—rights for casuals to convert to permanency. People who had been there for years, effectively doing full-time work, had never being entitled to the rights that go with permanent work. It shouldn't have needed a five-day strike to reach an agreement on a modest remuneration package for some of the lowest-paid workers who were receiving about half of the national average weekly earnings and barely more than the Australian minimum wage. That's what these workers were earning—barely more than the Australian minimum wage—for doing the unpleasant work that they do each and every day.

This legislation extends the function, also, of the Asbestos Safety and Eradication Agency, as other speakers have referred to. I want to speak about that for a moment as well. It does so specifically to address silica related diseases. Silica is becoming the new asbestos, condemning people who contract silicosis to a terrible fate. I've had a fair bit to do with asbestos victims in my state for the last two decades, and I understand full well what asbestos does to people and the terrible suffering that they have to endure in the last few years of their life and the number of people that have passed away from it.

Indeed, the member for Spence, who is in the chamber right now, and I will probably be attending the asbestos victims memorial service at Salisbury on the 24th of this month—it's at 10.30 at Pitman Park—which is run by the Asbestos Victims Association. I understand there's another one that's held on the same day by the Asbestos Diseases Society of South Australia at the Jack Watkins Reserve in Kilburn at one o'clock. We do so every year, and we hear the stories from those people who have suffered from asbestos diseases. It's a terrible way for your life to end.

But, with respect to the silica related diseases, I note that there is now a campaign to try and stamp out the use of engineered stone, commonly known by most people as Caesarstone, because that's the biggest company that manufactures it. I also note the push back from the Caesarstone manufacturers, saying: 'No, if you handle it properly with all the safeguards in place, you'll be fine. It doesn't present any problems.' The same could have been said about asbestos: if it were handled properly, it probably would present a minimum risk. But the reality is that it's killed thousands of people and there are thousands more that have also been condemned to death because they used it. The same will apply with silica, because the reality is that, in the world, not everybody is familiar with the correct ways of using it and sometimes people inadvertently have to deal with it and, again, can end up in that situation. Sadly, some of the people that have been directly affected by Caesarstone are people that are just in their 20s. They've hardly had a life, yet they now face a terminal illness.

I was pleased to see today that Bunnings has announced that, before the end of this year or by the end of this year, they will actually stop the sale of engineered stone throughout their stores. All due credit to them for taking that particular position, and I hope others do the same. I note that all of the state authorities are now looking to how they can better manage this problem, because, just as the manufacturers and suppliers of asbestos knew well over a hundred years ago that it was a deadly product but still continued to use it, so too do the manufacturers and resellers of engineered stone know that that, too, is a deadly product.

The last matter that I'll probably have time to speak about with respect to this is a matter that I have previously spoken about in this place on several occasions. I refer to the slave-like conditions and exploitation of seafarers working on foreign operated vessels. They are working within Australian waters carrying Australian cargo. The loopholes that allow those practices to continue must be closed. The Robbed at sea report of 2022, commissioned by the International Transport Workers Federation and based on 10 years of Australian data between 2012 and 2022, found that 70 per cent of ships carrying imports and exports failed to meet minimum international standards for wage payment. Quite frankly, from the stories I've heard, that doesn't surprise me at all. The ITF inspections also found that wage theft from seafarers is actually on the rise. So, even though we have these reports and even though we have made attempts over the years to try and stamp out the exploitation of seafarers, the reality is that it's on the rise. Again, I hope this legislation is able to assist in some way with respect to that.

Finally, I say this, and I note that other speakers have also raised this point. There are a lot of good businesses in this country who do the right thing and pay their employees the award level of wages. The problem for them is that they are also having to compete with those businesses that don't pay the right level of wages, and that is not fair to the people who are abiding by the laws of this country. Again, if for no other reason, it ought to be a level playing field for all out there and those who circumvent the level playing field shouldn't be able to do so through the very loopholes that this legislation is trying to close.

Finally, I note that all of the employer organisations who are strongly opposed to this legislation have pretty much in my time in this place consistently been those who have opposed everything else governments have tried to do to bring some fairness into the workplace. They are mainly the organisations that were backing the WorkChoices legislation of the Howard government era over a decade ago. They argued at the time that effectively—and this is my language—the sky would fall in if they didn't make the reforms they did. Well, the sky didn't fall in. The sky won't fall in if this legislation goes through the parliament. Indeed, there will be a better outcome for everybody involved. If some flaws or faults in the legislation emerge over time and through court proceedings, the government of the day will have every opportunity to tidy up those matters when they arise. But right here and now the reality is that too many workers in this country are being exploited, and their only remedy is legislation like this that will offer them the protection that they rightly deserve.

Ms WATSON-BROWN (Ryan) (22:11): The Fair Work Legislation Amendment (Closing Loopholes) Bill 2023 contains some good things, like criminalising wage theft, which is something the Greens have been calling for for some time now. The bill attempts to rein in labour hire to a limited extent so that it can't be used to sidestep enterprise bargaining agreements. The bill creates a new category to cover gig workers and give them some basic protections that have been missing for that sector. The provisions to criminalise wage theft are very welcome and long overdue, but they need to be equally applied to the payment of super, which is part of the wage.

I have to say that one of the biggest problems for workers in Australia today—the sheer amount of unpaid overtime expected—is simply not addressed in this bill. With the development of technology and the advent of remote work workers are more available than ever—24/7. This is only going to get worse unless we have a legislated right to disconnect that mandates contact with workers only in working hours, except of course in emergencies.

This raises the broader question of how much time we actually spend at work and how little time we have left for ourselves, our families and our communities. Australians are working too much. We're working too much overtime. We're on our work emails after hours. We're staying back late. Each Australian works six weeks of unpaid overtime per year. It's quite bizarre that we won the 40-hour week 75 years ago and, instead of reducing the work week further as technology progressed, we're actually working more hours a day now than back in the 1950s. In 1930 the great economist John Maynard Keynes said that we'd be working 15-hour weeks by now, but 1.4 million Australians are now working 50-hour weeks.

It's about time we started fighting for a four-day week. It may seem like a radical step, but so did the eight-hour day. A four-day week would transform our lives as significantly as the eight-hour day—more time for family, more time for friends, more time for doing the things that make life meaningful, more time for the beach, more time for community organisations and activities, and more time to raise kids. In fact, organisations across the world are already trialling a four-day work week and reporting huge mental health benefits, fewer sick days and increased overall productivity. Sounds great, doesn't it? Let's do it in Australia too. Since the recent Senate inquiry into care and work, the four-day week has received cross-party support. The federal government could be leading this charge by trialling a four-day work week in the public sector here. But it's clear from the small-target approach of this government that, if we're going to win a four-day week, we're going to need to fight for it, and that also means the union movement putting it front and centre.

This closing loopholes bill was an opportunity to address the power gap, that chasm, between the power of workers and employers in this country, ever widening since the neoliberal reforms of the eighties and nineties. Unfortunately, this bill is a failure on that score. That gap, that loophole, has not closed; it has widened. Why? Big corporations now effectively run Australia, and workers get crumbs. Why won't the Labor government address one of the key ways to fix that imbalance: restoring a real right to strike? Since this right was effectively removed, wage growth has steadily fallen behind productivity growth. Union density has fallen dramatically, down to an abysmal 12 per cent. So, while it's technically possible to go on strike in this country, unions and workers have to leap through so many hoops to do so. Thanks to laws implemented by both coalition and Labor governments, most just don't even bother. Other types of actions, like solidarity strikes, are completely illegal in this country.

Where has this led us? The other day, economist Alan Kohler, hardly a radical socialist, showed that, since the mid-seventies, workers' share of national income has declined from 62 per cent to 52 per cent despite corporate profits doubling. Corporate profits in this country are so high they're contributing significantly to inflation, causing even more pain for workers. Coles and Woolies are posting billions in profits while everyday Australians struggle to afford basic essentials.

The big banks are profiting off the pain of rising interest rates. The Commonwealth Bank posted a $10 billion profit, and ANZ posted a $7.4 billion profit. Meanwhile, locals in my electorate have told me that they're cutting back on basic essentials just to afford their skyrocketing mortgage payments. Fossil fuel corporations are exploiting our natural resources, shipping billions in profits overseas and making the climate crisis worse—and, by the way, climate-change-caused natural disasters have also been contributing to inflation. This is disastrous on so many levels. Meanwhile, many Australians can barely afford their energy bills, unable to cool their homes as we face the looming prospect of one of the hottest summers in recorded history.

How do we fix all this? How do we rein in corporate power? Part of the solution is to kick corporations out of this place, out of politics. Ban their donations and restrict their lobbying. The other part is restoring to workers a real right to strike so they can show big corporations they can't just keep exploiting us all.

ExxonMobil: $15 billion income; no tax paid. Qantas: $9 billion income; no tax paid. Shell: $9 billion income; no tax payable. Santos: $4.7 billion income. Australia's largest carbon emitter, AGL: $15 billion income; no tax paid. Singapore Telecom Australia, Singtel, the parent company of Optus—which is hardly an Australian hero right now, and who we've just now discovered contributed to the Optus meltdown last week—made $8 billion in income and paid not a single cent in income tax. That's all in the recent tax data release. Come on, people. One in three big corporations don't pay income tax, and corporate profits are hitting new highs.

Meanwhile, people's wages are going backwards and we're in a cost-of-living crisis. Families are struggling to put food on the table this holiday season. The RBA has just predicted that everyday people won't have the same purchasing power as they did before the pandemic until 2038—that's right: 15 years away. While these massive corporations make record profits, pay no tax and exploit workers, what's our government actually doing?

As the transport spokesperson for the Greens, I've chatted with many transport workers about their conditions and their pay. It's absolutely clear from their stories that far-reaching reform is necessary—far more than the piecemeal changes proposed in this bill. A real right to strike needs to be restored. Workers are currently reliant on this sort of government legislation to maintain the most basic conditions. Workers shouldn't have to wait for a friendly government in Canberra for a decent wage. They should be able to fight for those conditions themselves, backed by an empowered union unafraid to strike for fear of being fined.

In light of that, let's talk about Qantas—a prime example of many failures, including that of worker protection. It's a credit to the Transport Workers Union for pushing so strongly on the labour-hire provisions in this bill, but we shouldn't pretend this reform alone will restore the rights of the workers of Qantas and its subsidiaries. Recently, the High Court ruled Qantas' outsourcing of 1,700 ground workers during the pandemic was illegal. That's a great win for those workers and their union, but Qantas is required only to compensate those workers for lost wages. Those workers won't get their jobs back and they won't be compensated for their time fighting for that decision. Some words from the judgement summary are:

At the time of the outsourcing decision the affected employees were prohibited from organising or engaging in protected industrial action under the Act because the affected Qantas employees' enterprise agreement had not reached its nominal expiry date and the affected QGS employees were practically unable to take protected industrial action.

That means there was no way for those affected workers and their colleagues to go on strike and fight back against what turned out to be illegal outsourcing. This 'closing loopholes' legislation doesn't close that one.

Qantas has clearly shown it has absolutely no compunction about undermining workers' rights in its relentless pursuit of profits and in blatant defiance of the law. They've got a new CEO there, but that's no reason to believe Qantas management won't continue to exploit loopholes in labour laws. Qantas workers and others need their rights to bargain and fight back restored. They shouldn't have to wait for governments and the intervention of the courts for this. It's not just Qantas, either: Virgin Australia expects their employees to work on what can only be described as poverty wages. The Guardian reported yesterday that Virgin employees are raising serious safety concerns due to being overworked, often having to hold down a second or third job just to get by. Virgin have responded with a below-inflation pay offer.

Other workers are also suffering very badly from dreadful conditions. When Uber and other rideshare apps appeared in Australia, it disrupted the existing taxi industry to devastating effect. To drive a taxi in Australia you need a taxi licence. These cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, and many workers spend their entire lives paying them back. The introduction of unregulated rideshare companies means that many of these licences just aren't even worth the paper that they're printed on. The response to this by state governments has been completely inconsistent and inadequate. In Queensland, complaints by workers have been ignored, leaving workers at the mercy of a market in which taxi workers face intense scrutiny and are heavily regulated, while Uber and other rideshare companies' unregulated and exploitative gig-work platforms operate free of those constraints.

Without employment protections, gig workers suffer too, subject to low pay, poor safety conditions and long variable working hours. Two in three full-time gig workers earn less than minimum wage. Forty-five per cent of these workers struggle to afford groceries and household bills because they're paid by the minute, and only for driving or delivery time. This is appalling. Companies like Uber profit hugely off these workers' misery. The federal government needs to step in here to protect the workers, not the profits of these corporations. It's failure to do so in this 'closing loopholes' legislation leaves those loopholes gaping.

These problems aren't just confined to private corporations. Public sector workers have suffered decades of spending cuts and the undermining of their condition. The public sector is certainly no longer the benchmark of model employers. Poor work conditions have far-reaching effects beyond the workplace. I've been hearing from workers at the Civil Aviation Safety Authority who were recently able to strike for just half a day over what they say are unsafe staffing levels. They weren't concerned about themselves; they were concerned about our safety, the safety of the travelling public.

We all suffer the consequences of bad workplaces, not just the workers. The gutting of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority has meant that almost 40 per cent of workers are overworked and 65 per cent of the strikers agreed that this impacted the quality of safety assessments. Their work is highly technical and it's hugely risky if key workers are fatigued. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority should lead the charge in addressing these safety concerns, yet it's clear that senior management there is asleep at the wheel with the number of technical staff declining significantly over the last decade which is, frankly, exposing all of us to risk. Clearly a thorough review of the standards within CASA is urgently needed to make sure that workers are given the tools and supported to do their jobs safely for the safety of everyone, because I, for one, do not want to wait for another Lockhart River tragedy for something to be actually done. Thank you.

Mr Van Manen to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that the cost of living keeps going up under the Prime Minister and Treasurer, and since this Government took office:
(a) food and grocery prices are up by 8.2 per cent;
(b) housing prices are up by 10.4 per cent;
(c) insurance is up by 17 .3 per cent;
(d) electricity is up by 18.2 per cent;

(3) acknowledges that the Government has no plan to address spiralling costs and bring down inflation; and
(4) calls on the Government to deliver real cost of living relief to the Australian people.

That this House:
(1) notes:

(b) that Services Australia has become a basket case under the current Government, with sky-rocketing call and claims processing wait times; and
(c) that the under performing Minister for Government Services reduced Services Australia's average staffing levels in the 2023-24 budget and decreased funding for technology and transformation;
(2) acknowledges the work of the former Government in ensuring service delivery was seamless, simple and safe, with a strong emphasis on digital uplift; and
(3) calls on the Government to help get Services Australia back on track by launching a root and branch review into the embattled agency.
Ms Tink to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Migration Act 1958, and for related purposes. (Migration Amendment (Limits on Immigration Detention) Bill 2023)
Mr Coleman to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Online Safety Act 2021, and for related purposes. (Online Safety Amendment (Protecting Australian Children from Online Harm) Bill 2023)
Ms Claydon to move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) 25 November 2023 marks the United Nations' International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, beginning 16 days of activism against gender-based violence;
(b) in Australia, it has been publicly reported that approximately 47 women have been killed by acts of violence as of 9 November this year;
(c) one in three Australian women have experienced physical violence perpetrated by a man since the age of 15; and
(d) violence affects women of every age, from every cultural background, with different jobs and levels of education or income, living in different areas and leading different lives;
(2) commends the work of the family, domestic and sexual violence sector, which is delivering vital services to women, children and men;
(3) further notes that the Government is taking immediate and practical steps to prevent violence against women by:
(a) investing a record $2.3 billion in this area;
(b) launching the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-2032;
(c) establishing a dedicated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander action plan;
(d) establishing six ambitious targets to hold all governments to account for progress under the national plan;
(e) reducing the time it takes victim-survivors to access the Escaping Violence Payment;
(f) securing funding for states and territories to deliver frontline services;
(g) increasing support for temporary visa holders experiencing violence from $3,000 to $5,000;
(h) legislating ten paid days of family and domestic violence leave for all employees, including casuals; and
(i) making the family law system simpler and safer for people fleeing family violence; and
(4) acknowledges that there is still more work to done to end violence against women and children, but the Government is committed to ending this scourge within a generation.
Mr Thompson to move:
That this House:
(1) acknowledges:
(a) Australia's 370,000 first responders are the brave individuals on the frontline tackling compounding and cascading disasters, risking their lives to safeguard communities and property;
(b) the work of first responders is a service to our nation and we honour it, and that some experiences can be distressing, traumatic and dangerous;

(c) it is crucial to provide ongoing, comprehensive national support and enhance the resilience and capability of first responders, especially during and immediately after the current severe bushfire season; and

(d) Fortem Australia is the leading provider of this support for first responders nationwide, providing effective care to 15,000 unique first responders and their families across the nation, including 37,000 wellbeing activity registrations and delivery of over 6,100 clinical psychology sessions;

(2) notes the Government's delay in confirming additional continued funding for this important work to continue beyond March 2024, resulting in significant uncertainty and a risk that Fortem Australia will need to begin to scale down its operations from November 2023; and

(3) urgently calls upon the Government to announce continued funding for Fortem Australia prior to the commencement of the upcoming summer bushfire period, ensuring that first responders know where to tum in their time of need, and ensuring the seamless delivery of nation-leading support to these dedicated individuals.
Mr Georganas to move:
That this House:
(1) recognises that the Government's commitment to a Future Made in Australia includes pathways and access to the jobs of the future;
(2) acknowledges the Government's commitment to reach 1.2 million tech-related jobs by 2030 and ensure Australians are equipped with the skills needed for these jobs through;

(a) the delivery of over 180,000 Fee-Free TAFE places in 2023, including in the priority areas of technology and digital, and an additional 300,000 Fee-Free TAFE places to be made available from next year;
(b) its implementation of a Digital and Tech Skills Compact to help workers earn while they learn in entry leave tech roles;
(c) a diversity in STEM review to deliver a more diverse and representative STEM workforce for Australians from all walks of life;
(d) delivering Australia's first National Quantum Strategy;
(e) supporting the safe, inclusive uptake of technologies like artificial intelligence that reflect community interests; and
(3) notes the Government is committed to transforming Australian industry through:
(a) the $1.5 billion National Reconstruction Fund that will help Australia capture new, high value market opportunities; and
(b) the $392 million Industry Growth Program to support Australian small and medium enterprises to commercialise their ideas and grow their businesses.
Ms Steggall to move:
That this House:
(1) notes:
(a) small businesses are the backbone of our economy, making up 97.5 per cent of all businesses in Australia;
(b) these 2.5 million small businesses include cafes, newsagencies, hairdressers, builders and start-ups, all improving the way we live and work and contributing to Australia's low unemployment rate;

(c) many small businesses are facing the perfect storm of increased debt due to the COVID-19 pandemic, increasing interest rates, ongoing inflation and resulting decrease in consumer spending, labour shortages, reducing consumer confidence as well as the critical challenges of substantial industrial relations reform, cybersecurity, technological advancements and changes in the workforce;
(d) small businesses were significantly impacted by the recent Optus outage, costing some small businesses up to $10,000;
(e) that we must proactively support small businesses in adapting, innovating and maintaining productivity to survive these pressures; and
(2) calls on Government to:
(a) deliver immediate relief for energy costs;
(b) amend the Treasury Laws Amendment (Support for Small Business and Charities and Other Measures) Bill 2023 to:
(i) increase the amount and extend the period for the small business instant asset write off; and
(ii) increase the amount and extend the period for the small business energy initiative;

(c) ensure that any legislative changes to PayDay superannuation do not disproportionately impact small business and that measures are taken to improve cash flow for businesses to offset the impact of PayDay reform from 2023;
(d) take necessary steps to allow the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman to compel Optus to compensate small businesses for the November 2023 Optus mobile and broadband outage;
(e) implement a comprehensive tax system review over the longer term that specifically focuses on:
(i) simplifying small business and taxation reporting requirements;

(ii) investigating the potential to reduce tax for small businesses or afford them the same advantages as those offered to all corporations in the economy (for example, the concessions to fossil fuel companies under the Petroleum Rent Resource Tax); and
(iii) considers the potential for tax credits for small business including for the payment of Domestic Violence leave; and

(f) deliver a small business strategy, agreed by National Cabinet, to ensure all levels of government are working to reduce the burden on small business and acting to cut regulation to ensure the sustainability of small businesses around Australia.
Dr Reid to move:
That this House acknowledges the Government's commitment and actions to build a better and fairer education system from early education right through to university, by:

Mr Lim to move:

Mr Violi to move:
That this House:

CONSTITUENCY STATEMENTS

subdebateinfo.title: Youth Voice in Parliament Week, Education: Civics

p.span: Youth Voice in Parliament Week
Education: Civics

Ms SHARKIE (Mayo) (16:00): I am honoured today to read a speech by 11-year-old Emerson who attends Littlehampton Primary School in my electorate. Emerson took part in the 2023 Raise Our Voice competition, which encourages young people to consider what change they would like to make to make Australia a better place for future generations. He wrote about stopping plastic in the ocean, and many in my community know this is an area of great passion for me as well.
Emerson wrote:

I think that there should be more awareness on the subject and there should be more programs about the plastic problem in the sea. Even if there were more days to come together and clean the beaches and oceans, this act would be small but powerful. As a motivation to this idea maybe there could be a competition at each beach to see who could pick up the most plastic, and the winner would get rewarded at the end.

It is a very important subject and if we do not do something about it there might be catastrophic consequences in later years. It makes me wonder if technology could play a part in cleaning up the oceans, such as using drones and computers to locate the plastic and bring back small amounts back to land.
In my opinion we should also be trying to reduce the amount of plastic being used, I think that it will help the situation.
Thank you, Emerson.

This year I have thoroughly enjoyed listening to so many of my students across Mayo and visiting my schools, and I've been quite taken aback by the depth of civics knowledge that my students have. We do a mock parliament when I visit my schools. We have dress-ups and we even have our version of a mace. It's incredibly important that we teach civics to our students. Our young people need to know about the systems of government and parliament so that hopefully, one day, they too will be inspired to be part of the process and perhaps put their hand forward to be elected at the local, state or federal level.

I would like to mention some of those schools I visited this year: Saint Michael's Primary School; Kangaroo Island community school—both campuses—with our Speaker; Coromandel Valley Kindergarten; Hills Christian Community School; Lobethal Community Kindergarten; Clarendon Primary School; Mount Barker Waldorf School; Basket Range Primary School; Tatachilla Lutheran school; Callington Primary School; Heathfield Primary School; Gumeracha Primary School; Kangarilla Primary School; Nairne Primary School; Bridgewater Primary School; Upper Sturt Primary School; and Mount Barker South Primary School. And soon I'll be visiting Littlehampton Primary School, which is where young Emerson attends. It's fantastic to be able to get out to see my community, and I'm sure all members of parliament get out to their schools. I'm looking forward to seeing even more schools next year, in 2024.

subdebateinfo.title: Gorton Electorate: Religious and Cultural Organisations

p.span: Gorton Electorate: Religious and Cultural Organisations

Mr O'CONNOR (Gorton—Minister for Skills and Training) (16:03): Today I wish to share with the chamber my experiences and insights from recent visits to the vibrant religious temples in my electorate of Gorton.

Last week, I had the privilege of visiting the Sri Durga Temple located in Deanside in the western part of my electorate. Sri Durga is one of the largest Hindu temples, if not the largest, in Melbourne and certainly one of the largest in Australia. During a typical week, and particularly on weekends, literally thousands flock to this sacred space. Notably, nearly 75 per cent of these attendees reside in Melbourne's western suburbs, highlighting the significant role this temple plays in the lives of many of my constituents.

During my visit, I was met by Sri Durga Temple president, Kulwant Joshi, and other dedicated committee members. Their passion for community service and charitable initiatives was truly inspiring. I learnt about their efforts in providing food to those in need, underscoring the vital role religious institutions play in addressing social issues and fostering a sense of community responsibility.

This was the third temple I'd visited recently. Earlier this year, I went to Murugan Temple. It had recently received federal funding through the government's Stronger Communities Program for a well-needed upgrade to their kitchen facilities. Upon arrival, I was warmly received by the temple's president, Subramanium Dharmakularajah, and other committee members. The Murugan Temple stands not only as a place of worship for the temple community, but as a symbol of cultural preservation and identity. The commitment to maintaining traditions and values were evident during my visit, reinforcing the importance of religious institutions in preserving our diverse heritage.

On the same day I had the privilege of visiting the Paramitha Buddhist Temple, where I was graciously shown around by its president, Peter Perera, and the committee. Paramitha recently received a federal grant to assist in the building of a secure gate and fence for their car park. It's another step towards their goal of creating a serene oasis for those seeking spiritual practice and mindfulness. The peaceful atmosphere and the commitment to Buddhist teachings were on display. These temples are not just places of worship, however; they are community hubs that extend their impact far beyond religious practice. They serve as catalysts for charitable works, social cohesion and cultural preservation.

As representatives of diverse and dynamic communities, it is our responsibility to recognise and appreciate the valuable contributions religious institutions make. They play an integral role in fostering unity, compassion and social responsibility, and I urge my colleagues to continue supporting initiatives that ensure the flourishing of cultural and religious diversity in Gorton, recognising that it is a source of strength that binds us together. Let us all commit to supporting the endeavours of these religious and cultural organisations that contribute so significantly to the wellbeing of our constituents throughout the country.
Nicholls Electorate: Infrastructure

Mr BIRRELL (Nicholls—Deputy Nationals Whip) (16:06): One of the really good things about the previous coalition government was that it funded and built infrastructure. In my electorate, this included stage 3 of the Shepparton rail line upgrade, which is under construction at the moment; the Shepparton Art Museum, which is a great piece of cultural infrastructure; and the Echuca-Moama bridge. I was very pleased to walk across the Echuca-Moama bridge with the person who was then the infrastructure minister, the member for Gippsland. We were reflecting on governments that actually built things and have a legacy of things that actually improve productivity.

I'm very worried that we're not going to see anything get built in regional Victoria again. I'll give you an example. I fear the 90-day infrastructure review—now closing in on 200 days—has in its sights the Shepparton bypass project, a critical road project in one of the most important centres in the food bowl of Australia. It would take trucks out of the main CBD and, with a second bridge crossing, make it much easier for us to cross over the Goulburn River, which is a divide in our area. The coalition government committed 80 per cent of what was then the best guess at what the cost would be. The reason the coalition federal government did that was to try and drag a recalcitrant Victorian government to the table on that project. Now it's subject to the 90-day—or 200-day—review and I'm worried that it's going to get cut altogether. Of course, we know it needs more money, but this was an attempt by the previous coalition government to put some money on the table—and get the Victorian government to the table—to build some infrastructure.

I read this morning in the Herald Sun that we're moving away from 80-20 funding arrangements for infrastructure projects, whereby the federal government—which has more money, particularly compared to Victoria, which doesn't have much at all because of the management of the Andrews-Allan government—funds 80 per cent and the states fund 20 per cent, and instead moving to a fifty-fifty situation. That's why I say I fear that nothing will ever get built in Victoria again. Not only has the Victorian government blown the budget, but all of the money and focus seems to be on a crazy project called the Suburban Rail Loop, and Premier Allan is asking for more money for that pie-in-the-sky project. This is at the expense of critical infrastructure that supports where the money is made in regional Victoria: the Goulburn Valley. Road and rail projects are what we need to focus on, and the federal government needs to get to the table and start building things, as the previous coalition government did.

subdebateinfo.title: Eden-Monaro Electorate: Community Events, Eden-Monaro Electorate: Volunteers

p.span: Eden-Monaro Electorate: Community Events
Eden-Monaro Electorate: Volunteers

Ms McBAIN (Eden-Monaro—Minister for Regional Development, Local Government and Territories) (16:09): I rise today to say a big thankyou to the Philipzen family, a name that many families in the Bega Valley will be familiar with. It's synonymous with the Bega War Memorial Swimming Pool. The family has run the pool for more than 45 years. Phil Harris ran the pool for 39 years, before Phil's daughter, Zoe, and her husband, Mark, took over. As one of the families who has benefited from their hard work, I say thank you, and I wish you all the best in your next chapter, focusing on Henry. The public are invited to drop in to Bega War Memorial Swimming Pool between now and 28 March next year to share your stories and memories of their time running the pool.

A huge and heartfelt congratulations to Barbara Foster from Yass who has won the Centre for Volunteering Senior Volunteer of the Year. Barbara leads a small band of volunteers who open the New South Wales National Trust's Cooma Cottage and garden to visitors ranging from schoolchildren to historians, film crews to family reunions and weddings. Barbara's extensive role also includes organising major events like the recent 150th anniversary of the Hamilton Hume and William Hovell expedition. Thank you, Barbara, and well done for being recognised for your huge volunteering effort.

Another shoutout goes to the Queanbeyan Sleepbus team, which was recognised in the same awards for their ongoing support towards homelessness. The volunteer team provides small sleeping pods to those in our community sleeping rough, which comes with all that they need for an overnight stay. Since 2021, Sleepbus has helped more than 1,100 people with safe sleeps. Well done on winning this award. More importantly, thank you for everything you do week in and week out for our community. You are an amazing volunteer team and this is a great recognition.

I was recently one of 15,000 visitors who streamed through the gates at Murrumbateman Field Days. In the best of traditions, the field days are an opportunity for the country and the city to come together to see, experience and taste the best on offer. The Murrumbateman Field Days certainly delivered, with over 300 exhibitors. You could taste apples from Batlow, olives from the Gilmore Valley and bread from Murrumbateman. You could sample gin from Braidwood and Tumbarumba, beer from Tumut and wine from Murrumbateman. The food was amazing, with Yass Public School, Binalong Public School, the RFS and the Lions Club providing sausage sandwiches, scones and spuds to keep up our strength. The Murrumbateman Community Association does such a great job organising this, year in and year out, so make sure you book a weekend in Murrumbateman on 19 and 20 October next year, when the Murrumbateman Field Days will once again be held.

Lastly, a quick shout-out to Dr Corin Miller of Merimbula, who took out the Rural/Remote Health Professional of the Year award in the inaugural National Rural and Remote Health Awards last night.
